|`contend`
|

|`maintenance`
|

|`not_operational`
|

|`problematic`
|

|`uninitialized`
|

|`up`
|

|===

[id="types/device"]
=== Device [small]#struct#

A device wraps links to potential parents of a device.

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`comment`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Free text containing comments about this object.

|`description`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable description in plain text.

|`id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A unique identifier.

|`name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable name in plain text.

|===

.Links summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`instance_type`
|<<types/instance_type,InstanceType>>
|Optionally references to an instance type the device is used by.

|`template`
|<<types/template,Template>>
|Optionally references to a template the device is used by.

|`vm`
|<<types/vm,Vm>>
|Don't use this element, use `vms` instead.

|`vms`
|<<types/vm,Vm[]>>
|References to the virtual machines that are using this device.

|===

[id="types/device/links/vms"]
==== vms

References to the virtual machines that are using this device. A device may be used by several virtual machines;
for example, a shared disk my be used simultaneously by two or more virtual machines.

[id="types/disk"]
=== Disk [small]#struct#

Represents a virtual disk device.

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`active`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Indicates if the disk is visible to the virtual machine.

|`actual_size`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|The actual size of the disk, in bytes.

|`alias`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`backup`
|<<types/disk_backup,DiskBackup>>
|The backup behavior supported by the disk.

|`bootable`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Indicates if the disk is marked as bootable.

|`comment`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Free text containing comments about this object.

|`content_type`
|<<types/disk_content_type,DiskContentType>>
|Indicates the actual content residing on the disk.

|`description`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable description in plain text.

|`format`
|<<types/disk_format,DiskFormat>>
|The underlying storage format.

|`id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A unique identifier.

|`image_id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`initial_size`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|The initial size of a sparse image disk created on block storage, in bytes.

|`interface`
|<<types/disk_interface,DiskInterface>>
|The type of interface driver used to connect the disk device to the virtual machine.

|`logical_name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`lun_storage`
|<<types/host_storage,HostStorage>>
|

|`name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable name in plain text.

|`propagate_errors`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Indicates if disk errors should cause virtual machine to be paused or if disk errors should be
propagated to the the guest operating system instead.

|`provisioned_size`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|The virtual size of the disk, in bytes.

|`qcow_version`
|<<types/qcow_version,QcowVersion>>
|The underlying QCOW version of a QCOW volume.

|`read_only`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Indicates if the disk is in read-only mode.

|`sgio`
|<<types/scsi_generic_i_o,ScsiGenericIO>>
|Indicates whether SCSI passthrough is enable and its policy.

|`shareable`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Indicates if the disk can be attached to multiple virtual machines.

|`sparse`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Indicates if the physical storage for the disk should not be preallocated.

|`status`
|<<types/disk_status,DiskStatus>>
|The status of the disk device.

|`storage_type`
|<<types/disk_storage_type,DiskStorageType>>
|

|`total_size`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|The total size of the disk including all of its snapshots, in bytes.

|`uses_scsi_reservation`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|

|`wipe_after_delete`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Indicates if the disk's blocks will be read back as zeros after it is deleted:

- On block storage, the disk will be zeroed and only then deleted.

|===

[id="types/disk/attributes/active"]
==== active

Indicates if the disk is visible to the virtual machine.

IMPORTANT: When adding a disk attachment to a virtual machine, if the server accepts requests that do not contain
this attribute the result is undefined. In some cases the disk will be automatically activated
and in other cases it will not. To avoid issues it is strongly recommended to always include the this attribute
with the desired value.

[id="types/disk/attributes/actual_size"]
==== actual_size

The actual size of the disk, in bytes.

The actual size is the number of bytes actually used by the disk. It will be smaller than the provisioned
size for disks that use the `cow` format.

[id="types/disk/attributes/bootable"]
==== bootable

Indicates if the disk is marked as bootable.

IMPORTANT: This attribute only makes sense for disks that are actually connected to virtual machines, and in
version 4 of the API it has been moved to the <<types/disk_attachment, DiskAttachment>> type. It is preserved
here only for backwards compatibility, and it will be removed in the future.

[id="types/disk/attributes/initial_size"]
==== initial_size

The initial size of a sparse image disk created on block storage, in bytes.

The initial size is the number of bytes a sparse disk is initially allocated with when created on block storage.
The initial size will be smaller than the provisioned size. If not specified the default initial size used by the
system will be allocated.

[id="types/disk/attributes/interface"]
==== interface

The type of interface driver used to connect the disk device to the virtual machine.

IMPORTANT: This attribute only makes sense for disks that are actually connected to virtual machines, and in
version 4 of the API it has been moved to the <<types/disk_attachment, DiskAttachment>> type. It is preserved
here only for backwards compatibility, and it will be removed in the future.

[id="types/disk/attributes/provisioned_size"]
==== provisioned_size

The virtual size of the disk, in bytes.

This attribute is mandatory when creating a new disk.

[id="types/disk/attributes/qcow_version"]
==== qcow_version

The underlying QCOW version of a QCOW volume.
The QCOW version specifies to the qemu which qemu version the volume supports.
This field can be updated using the update API and will be reported only for QCOW volumes.
It is determined by the version of the storage domain that the disk is created on.
Storage domains with a version lower than V4 support QCOW2 volumes. V4 storage domains also support QCOW2v3.
For more information about features of the different QCOW versions, see http://wiki.qemu.org/Features/Qcow3[here].

[id="types/disk/attributes/read_only"]
==== read_only

Indicates if the disk is in read-only mode.

Since version 4.0 this attribute is not shown in the API and was moved to <<types/disk_attachment,DiskAttachment>>.

Since version 4.1.2 of {engine-name} this attribute is deprecated, and it will be removed in the future.
In order to attach a disk in read only mode use the `read_only` attribute of the <<types/disk_attachment,
DiskAttachment>> type. For example:

....
POST /ovirt-engine/api/vms/123/diskattachments
....

[source,xml]

<disk_attachment> <read_only>true</read_only> …​ </disk_attachment>

[id="types/disk/attributes/sgio"]
==== sgio

Indicates whether SCSI passthrough is enable and its policy.

Setting a value of `filtered`/`unfiltered` will enable SCSI passthrough for a LUN disk with unprivileged/privileged
SCSI I/O.
To disable SCSI passthrough the value should be set to `disabled`

[id="types/disk/attributes/shareable"]
==== shareable

Indicates if the disk can be attached to multiple virtual machines.

IMPORTANT: When a disk is attached to multiple virtual machines it is the responsibility of the guest
operating systems of those virtual machines to coordinate access to it, to avoid corruption of the data, for
example using a shared file system like https://www.gluster.org[GlusterFS] or
http://www.sourceware.org/cluster/gfs[GFS].

[id="types/disk/attributes/total_size"]
==== total_size

The total size of the disk including all of its snapshots, in bytes.

The total size is the number of bytes actually used by the disk plus the size of its snapshots.
It won't be populated for direct LUN and Cinder disks.
For disks without snapshots the total size is equal to the actual size.

[id="types/disk/attributes/wipe_after_delete"]
==== wipe_after_delete

Indicates if the disk's blocks will be read back as zeros after it is deleted:

- On block storage, the disk will be zeroed and only then deleted.

- On file storage, since the file system already guarantees that previously removed blocks are read back as
zeros, the disk will be deleted immediately.

.Links summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`disk_profile`
|<<types/disk_profile,DiskProfile>>
|

|`instance_type`
|<<types/instance_type,InstanceType>>
|Optionally references to an instance type the device is used by.

|`openstack_volume_type`
|<<types/open_stack_volume_type,OpenStackVolumeType>>
|

|`permissions`
|<<types/permission,Permission[]>>
|

|`quota`
|<<types/quota,Quota>>
|

|`snapshot`
|<<types/snapshot,Snapshot>>
|

|`statistics`
|<<types/statistic,Statistic[]>>
|Statistics exposed by the disk.

|`storage_domain`
|<<types/storage_domain,StorageDomain>>
|

|`storage_domains`
|<<types/storage_domain,StorageDomain[]>>
|The storage domains associated with this disk.

|`template`
|<<types/template,Template>>
|Optionally references to a template the device is used by.

|`vm`
|<<types/vm,Vm>>
|Don't use this element, use `vms` instead.

|`vms`
|<<types/vm,Vm[]>>
|References to the virtual machines that are using this device.

|===

[id="types/disk/links/statistics"]
==== statistics

Statistics exposed by the disk. For example:

[source,xml]

<statistics> <statistic href="/ovirt-engine/api/disks/123/statistics/456" id="456"> <name>data.current.read</name> <description>Read data rate</description> <kind>gauge</kind> <type>decimal</type> <unit>bytes_per_second</unit> <values> <value> <datum>1052</datum> </value> </values> <disk href="/ovirt-engine/api/disks/123" id="123"/> </statistic> …​ </statistics>

These statistics are not directly included when the disk is retrieved, only a link. To obtain the statistics
follow the included link:

....
GET /ovirt-engine/api/disks/123/statistics
....

[id="types/disk/links/storage_domains"]
==== storage_domains

The storage domains associated with this disk.

NOTE: Only required when the first disk is being added to a virtual machine that was not itself created from a
template.

[id="types/disk/links/vms"]
==== vms

References to the virtual machines that are using this device. A device may be used by several virtual machines;
for example, a shared disk my be used simultaneously by two or more virtual machines.

[id="types/disk_attachment"]
=== DiskAttachment [small]#struct#

Describes how a disk is attached to a virtual machine.

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`active`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Defines whether the disk is active in the virtual machine it's attached to.

|`bootable`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Defines whether the disk is bootable.

|`comment`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Free text containing comments about this object.

|`description`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable description in plain text.

|`id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A unique identifier.

|`interface`
|<<types/disk_interface,DiskInterface>>
|The type of interface driver used to connect the disk device to the virtual machine.

|`logical_name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The logical name of the virtual machine's disk, as seen from inside the virtual machine.

|`name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable name in plain text.

|`pass_discard`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Defines whether the virtual machine passes discard commands to the storage.

|`read_only`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Indicates whether the disk is connected to the virtual machine as read only.

|`uses_scsi_reservation`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Defines whether SCSI reservation is enabled for this disk.

|===

[id="types/disk_attachment/attributes/active"]
==== active

Defines whether the disk is active in the virtual machine it's attached to.

A disk attached to a virtual machine in an active status is connected to the virtual machine at run time and
can be used.

[id="types/disk_attachment/attributes/logical_name"]
==== logical_name

The logical name of the virtual machine's disk, as seen from inside the virtual machine.

The logical name of a disk is reported only when the guest agent is installed and running inside the virtual
machine.

For example, if the guest operating system is Linux and the disk is connected via a VirtIO interface, the
logical name will be reported as `/dev/vda`:

[source,xml]

<disk_attachment> …​ <logical_name>/dev/vda</logical_name> </disk_attachment>

If the guest operating system is Windows, the logical name will be reported as `\\.\PHYSICALDRIVE0`.

[id="types/disk_attachment/attributes/read_only"]
==== read_only

Indicates whether the disk is connected to the virtual machine as read only.

When adding a new disk attachment the default value is `false`.

[source,xml]

<disk_attachment> …​ <read_only>true</read_only> </disk_attachment>

[id="types/disk_attachment/attributes/uses_scsi_reservation"]
==== uses_scsi_reservation

Defines whether SCSI reservation is enabled for this disk.

Virtual machines with VIRTIO-SCSI passthrough enabled can set persistent SCSI reservations on disks. If they set
persistent SCSI reservations, those virtual machines cannot be migrated to a different host because they would
lose access to the disk, because SCSI reservations are specific to SCSI initiators, and therefore hosts. This
scenario cannot be automatically detected. To avoid migrating these virtual machines, the user can set this
attribute to `true`, to indicate the virtual machine is using SCSI reservations.

.Links summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`disk`
|<<types/disk,Disk>>
|The reference to the disk.

|`template`
|<<types/template,Template>>
|The reference to the template.

|`vm`
|<<types/vm,Vm>>
|The reference to the virtual machine.

|===

[id="types/disk_backup"]
=== DiskBackup [small]#enum#

Represents an enumeration of the backup mechanism
that is enabled on the disk.

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`incremental`
|Incremental backup support.

|`none`
|No backup support.

|===

[id="types/disk_content_type"]
=== DiskContentType [small]#enum#

The actual content residing on the disk.

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`data`
|The disk contains data.

|`hosted_engine`
|The disk contains the Hosted Engine VM disk.

|`hosted_engine_configuration`
|The disk contains the Hosted Engine configuration disk.

|`hosted_engine_metadata`
|The disk contains the Hosted Engine metadata disk.

|`hosted_engine_sanlock`
|The disk contains the Hosted Engine Sanlock disk.

|`iso`
|The disk contains an ISO image to be used a CDROM device.

|`memory_dump_volume`
|The disk contains a memory dump from a live snapshot.

|`memory_metadata_volume`
|The disk contains memory metadata from a live snapshot.

|`ovf_store`
|The disk is an OVF store.

|===

[id="types/disk_format"]
=== DiskFormat [small]#enum#

The underlying storage format of disks.

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`cow`
|The _Copy On Write_ format allows snapshots, with a small performance overhead.

|`raw`
|The raw format does not allow snapshots, but offers improved performance.

|===

[id="types/disk_interface"]
=== DiskInterface [small]#enum#

The underlying storage interface of disks communication with controller.

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`ide`
|Legacy controller device.

|`sata`
|SATA controller device.

|`spapr_vscsi`
|Para-virtualized device supported by the IBM pSeries family of machines, using the SCSI protocol.

|`virtio`
|Virtualization interface where just the guest's device driver knows it is running in a virtual environment.

|`virtio_scsi`
|Para-virtualized SCSI controller device.

|===

[id="types/disk_interface/values/ide"]
==== ide

Legacy controller device. Works with almost all guest operating systems, so it is good for compatibility.
Performance is lower than with the other alternatives.

[id="types/disk_interface/values/virtio"]
==== virtio

Virtualization interface where just the guest's device driver knows it is running in a virtual environment.
Enables guests to get high performance disk operations.

[id="types/disk_interface/values/virtio_scsi"]
==== virtio_scsi

Para-virtualized SCSI controller device. Fast interface with the guest via direct physical storage device
address, using the SCSI protocol.

[id="types/disk_profile"]
=== DiskProfile [small]#struct#

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`comment`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Free text containing comments about this object.

|`description`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable description in plain text.

|`id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A unique identifier.

|`name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable name in plain text.

|===

.Links summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`permissions`
|<<types/permission,Permission[]>>
|

|`qos`
|<<types/qos,Qos>>
|

|`storage_domain`
|<<types/storage_domain,StorageDomain>>
|

|===

[id="types/disk_snapshot"]
=== DiskSnapshot [small]#struct#

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`active`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Indicates if the disk is visible to the virtual machine.

|`actual_size`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|The actual size of the disk, in bytes.

|`alias`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`backup`
|<<types/disk_backup,DiskBackup>>
|The backup behavior supported by the disk.

|`bootable`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Indicates if the disk is marked as bootable.

|`comment`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Free text containing comments about this object.

|`content_type`
|<<types/disk_content_type,DiskContentType>>
|Indicates the actual content residing on the disk.

|`description`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable description in plain text.

|`format`
|<<types/disk_format,DiskFormat>>
|The underlying storage format.

|`id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A unique identifier.

|`image_id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`initial_size`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|The initial size of a sparse image disk created on block storage, in bytes.

|`interface`
|<<types/disk_interface,DiskInterface>>
|The type of interface driver used to connect the disk device to the virtual machine.

|`logical_name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`lun_storage`
|<<types/host_storage,HostStorage>>
|

|`name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable name in plain text.

|`propagate_errors`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Indicates if disk errors should cause virtual machine to be paused or if disk errors should be
propagated to the the guest operating system instead.

|`provisioned_size`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|The virtual size of the disk, in bytes.

|`qcow_version`
|<<types/qcow_version,QcowVersion>>
|The underlying QCOW version of a QCOW volume.

|`read_only`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Indicates if the disk is in read-only mode.

|`sgio`
|<<types/scsi_generic_i_o,ScsiGenericIO>>
|Indicates whether SCSI passthrough is enable and its policy.

|`shareable`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Indicates if the disk can be attached to multiple virtual machines.

|`sparse`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Indicates if the physical storage for the disk should not be preallocated.

|`status`
|<<types/disk_status,DiskStatus>>
|The status of the disk device.

|`storage_type`
|<<types/disk_storage_type,DiskStorageType>>
|

|`total_size`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|The total size of the disk including all of its snapshots, in bytes.

|`uses_scsi_reservation`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|

|`wipe_after_delete`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Indicates if the disk's blocks will be read back as zeros after it is deleted:

- On block storage, the disk will be zeroed and only then deleted.

|===

[id="types/disk_snapshot/attributes/active"]
==== active

Indicates if the disk is visible to the virtual machine.

IMPORTANT: When adding a disk attachment to a virtual machine, if the server accepts requests that do not contain
this attribute the result is undefined. In some cases the disk will be automatically activated
and in other cases it will not. To avoid issues it is strongly recommended to always include the this attribute
with the desired value.

[id="types/disk_snapshot/attributes/actual_size"]
==== actual_size

The actual size of the disk, in bytes.

The actual size is the number of bytes actually used by the disk. It will be smaller than the provisioned
size for disks that use the `cow` format.

[id="types/disk_snapshot/attributes/bootable"]
==== bootable

Indicates if the disk is marked as bootable.

IMPORTANT: This attribute only makes sense for disks that are actually connected to virtual machines, and in
version 4 of the API it has been moved to the <<types/disk_attachment, DiskAttachment>> type. It is preserved
here only for backwards compatibility, and it will be removed in the future.

[id="types/disk_snapshot/attributes/initial_size"]
==== initial_size

The initial size of a sparse image disk created on block storage, in bytes.

The initial size is the number of bytes a sparse disk is initially allocated with when created on block storage.
The initial size will be smaller than the provisioned size. If not specified the default initial size used by the
system will be allocated.

[id="types/disk_snapshot/attributes/interface"]
==== interface

The type of interface driver used to connect the disk device to the virtual machine.

IMPORTANT: This attribute only makes sense for disks that are actually connected to virtual machines, and in
version 4 of the API it has been moved to the <<types/disk_attachment, DiskAttachment>> type. It is preserved
here only for backwards compatibility, and it will be removed in the future.

[id="types/disk_snapshot/attributes/provisioned_size"]
==== provisioned_size

The virtual size of the disk, in bytes.

This attribute is mandatory when creating a new disk.

[id="types/disk_snapshot/attributes/qcow_version"]
==== qcow_version

The underlying QCOW version of a QCOW volume.
The QCOW version specifies to the qemu which qemu version the volume supports.
This field can be updated using the update API and will be reported only for QCOW volumes.
It is determined by the version of the storage domain that the disk is created on.
Storage domains with a version lower than V4 support QCOW2 volumes. V4 storage domains also support QCOW2v3.
For more information about features of the different QCOW versions, see http://wiki.qemu.org/Features/Qcow3[here].

[id="types/disk_snapshot/attributes/read_only"]
==== read_only

Indicates if the disk is in read-only mode.

Since version 4.0 this attribute is not shown in the API and was moved to <<types/disk_attachment,DiskAttachment>>.

Since version 4.1.2 of {engine-name} this attribute is deprecated, and it will be removed in the future.
In order to attach a disk in read only mode use the `read_only` attribute of the <<types/disk_attachment,
DiskAttachment>> type. For example:

....
POST /ovirt-engine/api/vms/123/diskattachments
....

[source,xml]

<disk_attachment> <read_only>true</read_only> …​ </disk_attachment>

[id="types/disk_snapshot/attributes/sgio"]
==== sgio

Indicates whether SCSI passthrough is enable and its policy.

Setting a value of `filtered`/`unfiltered` will enable SCSI passthrough for a LUN disk with unprivileged/privileged
SCSI I/O.
To disable SCSI passthrough the value should be set to `disabled`

[id="types/disk_snapshot/attributes/shareable"]
==== shareable

Indicates if the disk can be attached to multiple virtual machines.

IMPORTANT: When a disk is attached to multiple virtual machines it is the responsibility of the guest
operating systems of those virtual machines to coordinate access to it, to avoid corruption of the data, for
example using a shared file system like https://www.gluster.org[GlusterFS] or
http://www.sourceware.org/cluster/gfs[GFS].

[id="types/disk_snapshot/attributes/total_size"]
==== total_size

The total size of the disk including all of its snapshots, in bytes.

The total size is the number of bytes actually used by the disk plus the size of its snapshots.
It won't be populated for direct LUN and Cinder disks.
For disks without snapshots the total size is equal to the actual size.

[id="types/disk_snapshot/attributes/wipe_after_delete"]
==== wipe_after_delete

Indicates if the disk's blocks will be read back as zeros after it is deleted:

- On block storage, the disk will be zeroed and only then deleted.

- On file storage, since the file system already guarantees that previously removed blocks are read back as
zeros, the disk will be deleted immediately.

.Links summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`disk`
|<<types/disk,Disk>>
|

|`disk_profile`
|<<types/disk_profile,DiskProfile>>
|

|`instance_type`
|<<types/instance_type,InstanceType>>
|Optionally references to an instance type the device is used by.

|`openstack_volume_type`
|<<types/open_stack_volume_type,OpenStackVolumeType>>
|

|`permissions`
|<<types/permission,Permission[]>>
|

|`quota`
|<<types/quota,Quota>>
|

|`snapshot`
|<<types/snapshot,Snapshot>>
|

|`statistics`
|<<types/statistic,Statistic[]>>
|Statistics exposed by the disk.

|`storage_domain`
|<<types/storage_domain,StorageDomain>>
|

|`storage_domains`
|<<types/storage_domain,StorageDomain[]>>
|The storage domains associated with this disk.

|`template`
|<<types/template,Template>>
|Optionally references to a template the device is used by.

|`vm`
|<<types/vm,Vm>>
|Don't use this element, use `vms` instead.

|`vms`
|<<types/vm,Vm[]>>
|References to the virtual machines that are using this device.

|===

[id="types/disk_snapshot/links/statistics"]
==== statistics

Statistics exposed by the disk. For example:

[source,xml]

<statistics> <statistic href="/ovirt-engine/api/disks/123/statistics/456" id="456"> <name>data.current.read</name> <description>Read data rate</description> <kind>gauge</kind> <type>decimal</type> <unit>bytes_per_second</unit> <values> <value> <datum>1052</datum> </value> </values> <disk href="/ovirt-engine/api/disks/123" id="123"/> </statistic> …​ </statistics>

These statistics are not directly included when the disk is retrieved, only a link. To obtain the statistics
follow the included link:

....
GET /ovirt-engine/api/disks/123/statistics
....

[id="types/disk_snapshot/links/storage_domains"]
==== storage_domains

The storage domains associated with this disk.

NOTE: Only required when the first disk is being added to a virtual machine that was not itself created from a
template.

[id="types/disk_snapshot/links/vms"]
==== vms

References to the virtual machines that are using this device. A device may be used by several virtual machines;
for example, a shared disk my be used simultaneously by two or more virtual machines.

[id="types/disk_status"]
=== DiskStatus [small]#enum#

Current status representation for disk.

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`illegal`
|Disk cannot be accessed by the virtual machine, and the user needs
to take action to resolve the issue.

|`locked`
|The disk is being used by the system, therefore it cannot be accessed
by virtual machines at this point.

|`ok`
|The disk status is normal and can be accessed by the virtual machine.

|===

[id="types/disk_status/values/locked"]
==== locked

The disk is being used by the system, therefore it cannot be accessed
by virtual machines at this point. This is usually a temporary status,
until the disk is freed.

[id="types/disk_storage_type"]
=== DiskStorageType [small]#enum#

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`cinder`
|

|`image`
|

|`lun`
|

|`managed_block_storage`
|A storage type, used for a storage domain that was created
using a cinderlib driver.

|===

[id="types/disk_type"]
=== DiskType [small]#enum#

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`data`
|

|`system`
|

|===

[id="types/display"]
=== Display [small]#struct#

Represents a graphic console configuration.

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`address`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The IP address of the guest to connect the graphic console client to.

|`allow_override`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Indicates if to override the display address per host.

|`certificate`
|<<types/certificate,Certificate>>
|The TLS certificate in case of a TLS connection.

|`copy_paste_enabled`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Indicates whether a user is able to copy and paste content from an external host into the graphic console.

|`disconnect_action`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Returns the action that will take place when the graphic console is disconnected.

|`file_transfer_enabled`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Indicates if a user is able to drag and drop files from an external host into the graphic console.

|`keyboard_layout`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The keyboard layout to use with this graphic console.

|`monitors`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|The number of monitors opened for this graphic console.

|`port`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|The port address on the guest to connect the graphic console client to.

|`proxy`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The proxy IP which will be used by the graphic console client to connect to the guest.

|`secure_port`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|The secured port address on the guest, in case of using TLS, to connect the graphic console client to.

|`single_qxl_pci`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Indicates if to use one PCI slot for each monitor or to use a single PCI channel for all multiple monitors.

|`smartcard_enabled`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Indicates if to use smart card authentication.

|`type`
|<<types/display_type,DisplayType>>
|The graphic console protocol type.

|===

[id="types/display/attributes/allow_override"]
==== allow_override

Indicates if to override the display address per host.
Relevant only for the `Host.display` attribute.
If set, the graphical console address of a virtual machine will be overridden by the host specified display address.
if not set, the graphical console address of a virtual machine will not be overridden.

[id="types/display/attributes/certificate"]
==== certificate

The TLS certificate in case of a TLS connection.
If TLS isn't enabled then it won't be reported.

[id="types/display/attributes/copy_paste_enabled"]
==== copy_paste_enabled

Indicates whether a user is able to copy and paste content from an external host into the graphic console.
This option is only available for the SPICE console type.

[id="types/display/attributes/disconnect_action"]
==== disconnect_action

Returns the action that will take place when the graphic console is disconnected.
The options are:

none:: No action is taken.
lock_screen:: Locks the currently active user session.
logout:: Logs out the currently active user session.
reboot:: Initiates a graceful virtual machine reboot.
shutdown:: Initiates a graceful virtual machine shutdown.

This option is only available for the SPICE console type.

[id="types/display/attributes/file_transfer_enabled"]
==== file_transfer_enabled

Indicates if a user is able to drag and drop files from an external host into the graphic console.
This option is only available for the SPICE console type.

[id="types/display/attributes/keyboard_layout"]
==== keyboard_layout

The keyboard layout to use with this graphic console.
This option is only available for the VNC console type.
If no keyboard is enabled then it won't be reported.

[id="types/display/attributes/monitors"]
==== monitors

The number of monitors opened for this graphic console.
This option is only available for the SPICE console type.
Possible values are 1, 2 or 4.

[id="types/display/attributes/proxy"]
==== proxy

The proxy IP which will be used by the graphic console client to connect to the guest.
It is useful when the client is outside the guest's network.
This option is only available for the SPICE console type.
This proxy can be set in global configuration, cluster level, virtual machine pool level or disabled
per virtual machine.
If the proxy is set in any of this mentioned places and not disabled for the virtual machine, it will be
returned by this method.
If the proxy is not set, nothing will be reported.

[id="types/display/attributes/secure_port"]
==== secure_port

The secured port address on the guest, in case of using TLS, to connect the graphic console client to.
If TLS isn't enabled then it won't be reported.

[id="types/display/attributes/single_qxl_pci"]
==== single_qxl_pci

Indicates if to use one PCI slot for each monitor or to use a single PCI channel for all multiple monitors.
This option is only available for the SPICE console type and only for connecting a guest Linux based OS.

[id="types/display/attributes/smartcard_enabled"]
==== smartcard_enabled

Indicates if to use smart card authentication.
This option is only available for the SPICE console type.

[id="types/display_type"]
=== DisplayType [small]#enum#

Represents an enumeration of the protocol used
to connect to the graphic console of the virtual
machine.

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`spice`
|Display of type SPICE.

|`vnc`
|Display of type VNC.

|===

[id="types/display_type/values/spice"]
==== spice

Display of type SPICE.
See https://www.spice-space.org for more details.

[id="types/display_type/values/vnc"]
==== vnc

Display of type VNC. VNC stands for Virtual
Network Computing, and it is a graphical
desktop sharing system that uses RFB
(Remote Frame Buffer) protocol to remotely
control another machine.

[id="types/dns"]
=== Dns [small]#struct#

Represents the DNS resolver configuration.

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`search_domains`
|<<types/host,Host[]>>
|Array of hosts serving as search domains.

|`servers`
|<<types/host,Host[]>>
|Array of hosts serving as DNS servers.

|===

[id="types/dns_resolver_configuration"]
=== DnsResolverConfiguration [small]#struct#

Represents the DNS resolver configuration.

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`name_servers`
|<<types/string,String[]>>
|Array of addresses of name servers.

|===

[id="types/dns_resolver_configuration/attributes/name_servers"]
==== name_servers

Array of addresses of name servers. Either IPv4 or IPv6 addresses may be specified.

[id="types/domain"]
=== Domain [small]#struct#

This type represents a directory service domain.

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`comment`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Free text containing comments about this object.

|`description`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable description in plain text.

|`id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A unique identifier.

|`name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable name in plain text.

|`user`
|<<types/user,User>>
|

|===

.Links summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`groups`
|<<types/group,Group[]>>
|A reference to all groups in the directory service.

|`users`
|<<types/user,User[]>>
|A reference to a list of all users in the directory service.

|===

[id="types/domain/links/users"]
==== users

A reference to a list of all users in the directory service.
This information is used to add new users to the {product-name} environment.

[id="types/entity_external_status"]
=== EntityExternalStatus [small]#enum#

Type representing an external entity status.

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`error`
|The external entity status is erroneous.

|`failure`
|The external entity has an issue that causes failures.

|`info`
|There external entity status is okay but with some information that
might be relevant.

|`ok`
|The external entity status is okay.

|`warning`
|The external entity status is okay but with an issue that might require attention.

|===

[id="types/entity_external_status/values/error"]
==== error

The external entity status is erroneous. This might require a moderate attention.

[id="types/entity_external_status/values/failure"]
==== failure

The external entity has an issue that causes failures. This might require immediate attention.

[id="types/entity_profile_detail"]
=== EntityProfileDetail [small]#struct#

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`profile_details`
|<<types/profile_detail,ProfileDetail[]>>
|

|===

[id="types/error_handling"]
=== ErrorHandling [small]#struct#

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`on_error`
|<<types/migrate_on_error,MigrateOnError>>
|

|===

[id="types/event"]
=== Event [small]#struct#

Type representing an event.

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`code`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|The event code.

|`comment`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Free text containing comments about this object.

|`correlation_id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The event correlation identifier.

|`custom_data`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Free text representing custom event data.

|`custom_id`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|A custom event identifier.

|`description`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable description in plain text.

|`flood_rate`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|Defines the flood rate.

|`id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A unique identifier.

|`index`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|The numeric index of this event.

|`name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable name in plain text.

|`origin`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Free text identifying the origin of the event.

|`severity`
|<<types/log_severity,LogSeverity>>
|The event severity.

|`time`
|<<types/date,Date>>
|The event time.

|===

[id="types/event/attributes/correlation_id"]
==== correlation_id

The event correlation identifier. Used in order to correlate
several events together.

[id="types/event/attributes/flood_rate"]
==== flood_rate

Defines the flood rate.
This prevents flooding in case an event appeared
more than once in the defined rate.
Defaults is 30 seconds.

[id="types/event/attributes/index"]
==== index

The numeric index of this event. The indexes of events are always increasing, so events with higher indexes
are guaranteed to be older than events with lower indexes.

IMPORTANT: In the current implementation of the engine, the `id` attribute has the same value as this
`index` attribute. That is an implementation detail that the user of the API should not rely on. In the future
the `id` attribute may be changed to an arbitrary string, containing non numeric characters and no implicit
order. On the other hand this `index` attribute is guaranteed to stay as integer and ordered.

.Links summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`cluster`
|<<types/cluster,Cluster>>
|Reference to the cluster service.

|`data_center`
|<<types/data_center,DataCenter>>
|Reference to the data center service.

|`host`
|<<types/host,Host>>
|Reference to the host service.

|`storage_domain`
|<<types/storage_domain,StorageDomain>>
|Reference to the storage domain service.

|`template`
|<<types/template,Template>>
|Reference to the template service.

|`user`
|<<types/user,User>>
|Reference to the user service.

|`vm`
|<<types/vm,Vm>>
|Reference to the virtual machine service.

|===

[id="types/event/links/cluster"]
==== cluster

Reference to the cluster service.
Event can be associated with a cluster.

[id="types/event/links/data_center"]
==== data_center

Reference to the data center service.
Event can be associated with a data center.

[id="types/event/links/host"]
==== host

Reference to the host service.
Event can be associated with a host.

[id="types/event/links/storage_domain"]
==== storage_domain

Reference to the storage domain service.
Event can be associated with a storage domain.

[id="types/event/links/template"]
==== template

Reference to the template service.
Event can be associated with a template.

[id="types/event/links/user"]
==== user

Reference to the user service.
Event can be associated with a user.

[id="types/event/links/vm"]
==== vm

Reference to the virtual machine service.
Event can be associated with a virtual machine.

[id="types/event_subscription"]
=== EventSubscription [small]#struct#

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`address`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The email address to which notifications should be sent.

|`comment`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Free text containing comments about this object.

|`description`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable description in plain text.

|`event`
|<<types/notifiable_event,NotifiableEvent>>
|The subscribed-for event.

|`id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A unique identifier.

|`name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable name in plain text.

|`notification_method`
|<<types/notification_method,NotificationMethod>>
|The notification method: SMTP or SNMP.

|`user`
|<<types/user,User>>
|The subscribing user.

|===

[id="types/event_subscription/attributes/address"]
==== address

The email address to which notifications should be sent.

When not provided, notifications are sent to the user's email.
Only a single address per user is currently supported. If a
subscription with a different email address to that of existing
subscriptions is added, a 409 (CONFLICT) status is returned with
an explanation that the provided address conflicts with an existing
address of an event-subscription for this user.

This field might be deprecated in the future, and notifications
will always be sent on the user's email address.

[id="types/event_subscription/attributes/event"]
==== event

The subscribed-for event.

(Combined with the user, Uniquely identifies the event-subscription).

[id="types/event_subscription/attributes/notification_method"]
==== notification_method

The notification method: SMTP or SNMP.

Currently only SMTP supported by API. Support for SNMP
will be added in the future.

[id="types/event_subscription/attributes/user"]
==== user

The subscribing user.

Combined with the event-name, uniquely identifies the event-subscription.

[id="types/external_host"]
=== ExternalHost [small]#struct#

Represents a host provisioned by a host
provider (such as Foreman/Satellite).

See https://www.theforeman.org/ for more details on Foreman.
See https://access.redhat.com/products/red-hat-satellite
for more details on Red Hat Satellite.

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`address`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The address of the host, either IP address
of FQDN (Fully Qualified Domain Name).

|`comment`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Free text containing comments about this object.

|`description`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable description in plain text.

|`id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A unique identifier.

|`name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable name in plain text.

|===

.Links summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`external_host_provider`
|<<types/external_host_provider,ExternalHostProvider>>
|A reference to the external host provider
that the host is managed by.

|===

[id="types/external_host_group"]

|`description`
|<<types/string,String>>

|`domain_name`
|<<types/string,String>>

|`id`

[id="types/external_host_provider"]
=== ExternalHostProvider [small]#struct#

Represents an external host provider,
such as Foreman or Satellite.

See https://www.theforeman.org/ for more details on Foreman.
See https://access.redhat.com/products/red-hat-satellite
for more details on Red Hat Satellite.

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`authentication_url`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Defines the external provider authentication URL address.

|`comment`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Free text containing comments about this object.

|`description`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable description in plain text.

|`id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A unique identifier.

|`name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable name in plain text.

|`password`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Defines password for the user during the authentication process.

|`properties`
|<<types/property,Property[]>>
|Array of provider name/value properties.

|`requires_authentication`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Defines whether provider authentication is required or not.

|`url`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Defines URL address of the external provider.

|`username`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Defines user name to be used during authentication process.

|===

[id="types/external_host_provider/attributes/requires_authentication"]
==== requires_authentication

Defines whether provider authentication is required or not.

If authentication is required, both `username` and `password` attributes will be used during authentication.

.Links summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`certificates`
|<<types/certificate,Certificate[]>>
|A reference to the certificates the engine supports
for this provider.

|`compute_resources`
|<<types/external_compute_resource,ExternalComputeResource[]>>
|A reference to the compute resource as represented in the host provider.

|`discovered_hosts`
|<<types/external_discovered_host,ExternalDiscoveredHost[]>>
|A reference to the discovered hosts in the host provider.

|`host_groups`
|<<types/external_host_group,ExternalHostGroup[]>>
|A reference to the host groups in the host provider.

|`hosts`
|<<types/host,Host[]>>
|A reference to the hosts provisioned by the host provider.

|===

[id="types/external_host_provider/links/compute_resources"]
==== compute_resources

A reference to the compute resource as represented in the host provider.
Each host provider optionally has the engine defined as a compute resource,
which allows to create virtual machines in the engine. This compute resource
details are used in the Bare-Metal provisioning use-case, in order to
deploy the hypervisor.

[id="types/external_host_provider/links/discovered_hosts"]
==== discovered_hosts

A reference to the discovered hosts in the host provider.
Discovered hosts are hosts that were not provisioned yet.

[id="types/external_host_provider/links/host_groups"]
==== host_groups

A reference to the host groups in the host provider.
Host group contains different properties that the host
provider applies on all hosts that are member of this group.
Such as installed software, system definitions, passwords and more.

[id="types/external_provider"]

If authentication is required, both `username` and `password` attributes will be used during authentication.

[id="types/external_status"]
=== ExternalStatus [small]#enum#

Represents an external status.
This status is currently used for <<types/host, hosts>>
and <<types/storage_domain, storage domains>>, and allows an external
system to update status of objects it is aware of.

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`error`
|Error status.

|`failure`
|Failure status.

|`info`
|Info status.

|`ok`
|OK status.

|`warning`
|Warning status.

|===

[id="types/external_status/values/error"]
==== error

Error status. There is some kind of error
in the relevant object.

[id="types/external_status/values/failure"]
==== failure

Failure status. The relevant object is failing.

[id="types/external_status/values/info"]
==== info

Info status. The relevant object is in OK status,
but there is an information available that might be
relevant for the administrator.

[id="types/external_status/values/ok"]
==== ok

OK status. The relevant object is working well.

[id="types/external_status/values/warning"]
==== warning

Warning status. The relevant object is working well,
but there is some warning that might be relevant for
the administrator.

[id="types/external_system_type"]
=== ExternalSystemType [small]#enum#

Represents the type of the external system that is associated with the `step`.

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`gluster`
|Represents `Gluster` as the external system which is associated with the `step`.

|`vdsm`
|Represents `VDSM` as the external system which is associated with the `step`.

|===

[id="types/external_vm_import"]
=== ExternalVmImport [small]#struct#

Describes the parameters for the virtual machine import operation from an external system.

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The name of the virtual machine to be imported, as is defined within the external system.

|`password`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The password to authenticate against the external hypervisor system.

|`provider`
|<<types/external_vm_provider_type,ExternalVmProviderType>>
|The type of external virtual machine provider.

|`sparse`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Specifies the disk allocation policy of the resulting virtual machine: `true` for sparse, `false` for preallocated.

|`url`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The URL to be passed to the `virt-v2v` tool for conversion.

|`username`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The username to authenticate against the external hypervisor system.

|===

[id="types/external_vm_import/attributes/url"]
==== url

The URL to be passed to the `virt-v2v` tool for conversion.

Example:

[source]

vpx://wmware_user@vcenter-host/DataCenter/Cluster/esxi-host?no_verify=1

More examples can be found at http://libguestfs.org/virt-v2v.1.html.

.Links summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`cluster`
|<<types/cluster,Cluster>>
|Specifies the target cluster for the resulting virtual machine.

|`cpu_profile`
|<<types/cpu_profile,CpuProfile>>
|Optional.

|`drivers_iso`
|<<types/file,File>>
|Optional.

|`host`
|<<types/host,Host>>
|Optional.

|`quota`
|<<types/quota,Quota>>
|Optional.

|`storage_domain`
|<<types/storage_domain,StorageDomain>>
|Specifies the target storage domain for converted disks.

|`vm`
|<<types/vm,Vm>>
|The virtual machine entity used to specify a name for the newly created virtual machine.

|===

[id="types/external_vm_import/links/cpu_profile"]
==== cpu_profile

Optional. Specifies the CPU profile of the resulting virtual machine.

[id="types/external_vm_import/links/drivers_iso"]
==== drivers_iso

Optional. The name of the ISO containing drivers that can be used during the `virt-v2v` conversion process.

[id="types/external_vm_import/links/host"]
==== host

Optional. Specifies the host (using host's ID) to be used for the conversion process.
If not specified, one is selected automatically.

[id="types/external_vm_import/links/quota"]
==== quota

Optional. Specifies the quota that will be applied to the resulting virtual machine.

[id="types/external_vm_import/links/vm"]
==== vm

The virtual machine entity used to specify a name for the newly created virtual machine.

If a name is not specified, the source virtual machine name will be used.

[id="types/external_vm_provider_type"]

.Values summary

|===
|Name |Summary

|`kvm`
|

|`vmware`

|`xen`

[id="types/fence_type"]
=== FenceType [small]#enum#

Type representing the type of the fence operation.

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`manual`
|Manual host fencing via power management.

|`restart`
|Restart the host via power management.

|`start`
|Start the host via power management.

|`status`
|Check the host power status via power management.

|`stop`
|Stop the host via power management.

|===

[id="types/fencing_policy"]
=== FencingPolicy [small]#struct#

Type representing a cluster fencing policy.

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`enabled`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Enable or disable fencing on this cluster.

|`skip_if_connectivity_broken`
|<<types/skip_if_connectivity_broken,SkipIfConnectivityBroken>>
|If enabled, we will not fence a host
in case more than a configurable percentage
of hosts in the cluster lost connectivity as well.

|`skip_if_gluster_bricks_up`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|A flag indicating if fencing should be skipped if Gluster bricks are up and running in the host being fenced.

|`skip_if_gluster_quorum_not_met`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|A flag indicating if fencing should be skipped if Gluster bricks are up and running and Gluster quorum will not
be met without those bricks.

|`skip_if_sd_active`
|<<types/skip_if_sd_active,SkipIfSdActive>>
|If enabled, we will skip fencing in case the host
maintains its lease in the storage.

|===

[id="types/fencing_policy/attributes/skip_if_connectivity_broken"]
==== skip_if_connectivity_broken

If enabled, we will not fence a host
in case more than a configurable percentage
of hosts in the cluster lost connectivity as well.
This comes to prevent fencing _storm_ in cases
where there is a global networking issue in the
cluster.

[id="types/fencing_policy/attributes/skip_if_gluster_bricks_up"]
==== skip_if_gluster_bricks_up

A flag indicating if fencing should be skipped if Gluster bricks are up and running in the host being fenced.
This flag is optional, and the default value is `false`.

[id="types/fencing_policy/attributes/skip_if_gluster_quorum_not_met"]
==== skip_if_gluster_quorum_not_met

A flag indicating if fencing should be skipped if Gluster bricks are up and running and Gluster quorum will not
be met without those bricks.
This flag is optional, and the default value is `false`.

[id="types/fencing_policy/attributes/skip_if_sd_active"]
==== skip_if_sd_active

If enabled, we will skip fencing in case the host
maintains its lease in the storage. It means that
if the host still has storage access then it won't
get fenced.

[id="types/firewall_type"]
=== FirewallType [small]#enum#

Describes all firewall types supported by the system.

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`firewalld`
|FirewallD firewall type.

|`iptables`
|IPTables firewall type.

|===

[id="types/firewall_type/values/firewalld"]
==== firewalld

FirewallD firewall type.

When a cluster has the firewall type set to `firewalld`, the firewalls of all hosts in the cluster will be configured
using `firewalld`. http://www.firewalld.org[FirewallD] replaced IPTables in version 4.2. It simplifies
configuration using a command line program and dynamic configuration.

[id="types/firewall_type/values/iptables"]
==== iptables

IPTables firewall type.

When a cluster has the firewall type set to `iptables`, the firewalls of all hosts in the cluster will be configured using
`iptables`. `iptables` adds firewall rules to `/etc/sysconfig/iptables` using a special `iptables` syntax. For
more information, see the `iptables` manual page.

`iptables` is deprecated in cluster version 4.2 and will be removed in cluster version 4.3.

[id="types/floppy"]
=== Floppy [small]#struct#

The underlying representation of a floppy file.

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`comment`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Free text containing comments about this object.

|`description`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable description in plain text.

|`file`
|<<types/file,File>>
|File object that represent the Floppy device's content and its type.

|`id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A unique identifier.

|`name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable name in plain text.

|===

.Links summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`instance_type`
|<<types/instance_type,InstanceType>>
|Optionally references to an instance type the device is used by.

|`template`
|<<types/template,Template>>
|Optionally references to a template the device is used by.

|`vm`
|<<types/vm,Vm>>
|Don't use this element, use `vms` instead.

|`vms`
|<<types/vm,Vm[]>>
|References to the virtual machines that are using this device.

|===

[id="types/floppy/links/vms"]
==== vms

References to the virtual machines that are using this device. A device may be used by several virtual machines;
for example, a shared disk my be used simultaneously by two or more virtual machines.

[id="types/fop_statistic"]

|<<types/string,String>>

|`statistics`

|===

[id="types/gluster_brick"]
=== GlusterBrick [small]#struct#

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`brick_dir`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`comment`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Free text containing comments about this object.

|`description`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable description in plain text.

|`device`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`fs_name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`gluster_clients`
|<<types/gluster_client,GlusterClient[]>>
|

|`id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A unique identifier.

|`memory_pools`
|<<types/gluster_memory_pool,GlusterMemoryPool[]>>
|

|`mnt_options`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable name in plain text.

|`pid`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|

|`port`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|

|`server_id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`status`
|<<types/gluster_brick_status,GlusterBrickStatus>>
|

|===

.Links summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`gluster_volume`
|<<types/gluster_volume,GlusterVolume>>
|

|`instance_type`
|<<types/instance_type,InstanceType>>
|Optionally references to an instance type the device is used by.

|`statistics`
|<<types/statistic,Statistic[]>>
|

|`template`
|<<types/template,Template>>
|Optionally references to a template the device is used by.

|`vm`
|<<types/vm,Vm>>
|Don't use this element, use `vms` instead.

|`vms`
|<<types/vm,Vm[]>>
|References to the virtual machines that are using this device.

|===

[id="types/gluster_brick/links/vms"]
==== vms

References to the virtual machines that are using this device. A device may be used by several virtual machines;
for example, a shared disk my be used simultaneously by two or more virtual machines.

[id="types/gluster_brick_status"]
=== GlusterBrickStatus [small]#enum#

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`down`
|Brick is in `down` state, the data cannot be stored or retrieved from it.

|`unknown`
|When the status cannot be determined due to host being non-responsive.

|`up`
|Brick is in `up` state, the data can be stored or retrieved from it.

|===

[id="types/gluster_volume"]

[id="types/gluster_volume_status"]
=== GlusterVolumeStatus [small]#enum#

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`down`
|Volume needs to be started, for clients to be able to mount and use it.

|`unknown`
|When the status cannot be determined due to host being non-responsive.

|`up`
|Volume is started, and can be mounted and used by clients.

|===

[id="types/gluster_volume_type"]
=== GlusterVolumeType [small]#enum#

Type representing the type of Gluster Volume.

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`disperse`
|Dispersed volumes are based on erasure codes, providing space-efficient protection against disk or server
failures.

|`distribute`
|Distributed volumes distributes files throughout the bricks in the volume.

|`distributed_disperse`
|Distributed dispersed volumes distribute files across dispersed subvolumes.

|`distributed_replicate`
|Distributed replicated volumes distributes files across replicated bricks in the volume.

|`distributed_stripe`
|Distributed striped volumes stripe data across two or more nodes in the cluster.

|`distributed_striped_replicate`
|Distributed striped replicated volumes distributes striped data across replicated bricks in the cluster.

|`replicate`
|Replicated volumes replicates files across bricks in the volume.

|`stripe`
|Striped volumes stripes data across bricks in the volume.

|`striped_replicate`
|Striped replicated volumes stripes data across replicated bricks in the cluster.

|===

[id="types/gluster_volume_type/values/disperse"]
==== disperse

Dispersed volumes are based on erasure codes, providing space-efficient protection against disk or server
failures.

Dispersed volumes an encoded fragment of the original file to each brick in a way that only a subset of the
fragments is needed to recover the original file. The number of bricks that can be missing without losing access
to data is configured by the administrator on volume creation time.

[id="types/gluster_volume_type/values/distribute"]
==== distribute

Distributed volumes distributes files throughout the bricks in the volume.

Distributed volumes can be used where the requirement is to scale storage and the redundancy is either not
important or is provided by other hardware/software layers.

[id="types/gluster_volume_type/values/distributed_disperse"]
==== distributed_disperse

Distributed dispersed volumes distribute files across dispersed subvolumes.

This has the same advantages of distribute replicate volumes, but using disperse to store the data into the
bricks.

[id="types/gluster_volume_type/values/distributed_replicate"]
==== distributed_replicate

Distributed replicated volumes distributes files across replicated bricks in the volume.

Distributed replicated volumes can be used in environments where the requirement is to scale storage and
high-reliability is critical. Distributed replicated volumes also offer improved read performance in most
environments.

[id="types/gluster_volume_type/values/distributed_stripe"]
==== distributed_stripe

Distributed striped volumes stripe data across two or more nodes in the cluster.

Distributed striped volumes should be used where the requirement is to scale storage and in high concurrency
environments accessing very large files is critical.

Note: With the introduction of Sharding in Glusterfs 3.7 releases, striped volumes are not recommended and it
will be removed in future release.

[id="types/gluster_volume_type/values/distributed_striped_replicate"]
==== distributed_striped_replicate

Distributed striped replicated volumes distributes striped data across replicated bricks in the cluster.

For best results, distributed striped replicated volumes should be used in highly concurrent environments where
parallel access of very large files and performance is critical.

Note: With the introduction of Sharding in Glusterfs 3.7 releases, striped volumes are not recommended and it
will be removed in future release.

[id="types/gluster_volume_type/values/replicate"]
==== replicate

Replicated volumes replicates files across bricks in the volume.

Replicated volumes can be used in environments where high-availability and high-reliability are critical.

[id="types/gluster_volume_type/values/stripe"]
==== stripe

Striped volumes stripes data across bricks in the volume.

For best results, striped volumes should only in high concurrency environments accessing very large files.

Note: With the introduction of Sharding in Glusterfs 3.7 releases, striped volumes are not recommended and it
will be removed in future release.

[id="types/gluster_volume_type/values/striped_replicate"]
==== striped_replicate

Striped replicated volumes stripes data across replicated bricks in the cluster.

For best results, striped replicated volumes should be used in highly concurrent environments where there is
parallel access of very large files and performance is critical.

Note: With the introduction of Sharding in Glusterfs 3.7 releases, striped volumes are not recommended and it
will be removed in future release.

[id="types/grace_period"]

[id="types/graphics_type"]
=== GraphicsType [small]#enum#

The graphics protocol used to connect to the graphic console.

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`spice`
|Graphics protocol of type SPICE.

|`vnc`
|Graphics protocol of type VNC.

|===

[id="types/graphics_type/values/spice"]
==== spice

Graphics protocol of type SPICE.
See https://www.spice-space.org for more details.

[id="types/graphics_type/values/vnc"]
==== vnc

Graphics protocol of type VNC. VNC stands for Virtual
Network Computing, and it is a graphical
desktop sharing system that uses RFB
(Remote Frame Buffer) protocol to remotely
control another machine.

[id="types/group"]
=== Group [small]#struct#

This type represents all groups in the directory service.

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`comment`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Free text containing comments about this object.

|`description`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable description in plain text.

|`domain_entry_id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The containing directory service domain id.

|`id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A unique identifier.

|`name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable name in plain text.

|`namespace`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Namespace where group resides.

|===

.Links summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`domain`
|<<types/domain,Domain>>
|A link to the domain containing this group.

|`permissions`
|<<types/permission,Permission[]>>
|A link to the permissions sub-collection for permissions attached to this group.

|`roles`
|<<types/role,Role[]>>
|A link to the roles sub-collection for roles attached to this group.

|`tags`
|<<types/tag,Tag[]>>
|A link to the tags sub-collection for tags attached to this group.

|===

[id="types/group/links/roles"]
==== roles

A link to the roles sub-collection for roles attached to this group.

Used only to represent the initial role assignments for a new group; thereafter, modification of role assignments
is only supported via the `roles` sub-collection.

[id="types/guest_operating_system"]
=== GuestOperatingSystem [small]#struct#

Represents an operating system installed on the virtual machine.

To get that information send a request like this:

....
GET /ovirt-engine/api/vms/123
....

The result will be like this:

[source,xml]

<vm href="/ovirt-engine/api/vms/123" id="123"> …​ <guest_operating_system> <architecture>x86_64</architecture> <codename>Maipo</codename> <distribution>Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server</distribution> <family>Linux</family> <kernel> <version> <build>0</build> <full_version>3.10.0-514.10.2.el7.x86_64</full_version> <major>3</major> <minor>10</minor> <revision>514</revision> </version> </kernel> <version> <full_version>7.3</full_version> <major>7</major> <minor>3</minor> </version> </guest_operating_system> </vm>

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`architecture`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The architecture of the operating system, such as x86_64.

|`codename`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Code name of the operating system, such as `Maipo`.

|`distribution`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Full name of operating system distribution.

|`family`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Family of operating system, such as `Linux`.

|`kernel`
|<<types/kernel,Kernel>>
|Kernel version of the operating system.

|`version`
|<<types/version,Version>>
|Version of the installed operating system.

|===

[id="types/hardware_information"]
=== HardwareInformation [small]#struct#

Represents hardware information of host.

To get that information send a request like this:

....
GET /ovirt-engine/api/hosts/123
....

The result will be like this:

[source,xml]

<host href="/ovirt-engine/api/hosts/123" id="123"> …​ <hardware_information> <family>Red Hat Enterprise Linux</family> <manufacturer>Red Hat</manufacturer> <product_name>RHEV Hypervisor</product_name> <serial_number>01234567-89AB-CDEF-0123-456789ABCDEF</serial_number> <supported_rng_sources> <supported_rng_source>random</supported_rng_source> </supported_rng_sources> <uuid>12345678-9ABC-DEF0-1234-56789ABCDEF0</uuid> <version>1.2-34.5.el7ev</version> </hardware_information> …​ </application>

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`family`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Type of host's CPU.

|`manufacturer`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Manufacturer of the host's machine and hardware vendor.

|`product_name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Host's product name (for example `RHEV Hypervisor`).

|`serial_number`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Unique ID for host's chassis.

|`supported_rng_sources`
|<<types/rng_source,RngSource[]>>
|Supported sources of random number generator.

|`uuid`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Unique ID for each host.

|`version`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Unique name for each of the manufacturer.

|===

[id="types/high_availability"]
=== HighAvailability [small]#struct#

Type representing high availability of a virtual machine.

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`enabled`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Define if the virtual machine is considered highly available.

|`priority`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|Indicates the priority of the virtual machine inside the run and migration queues.

|===

[id="types/high_availability/attributes/enabled"]
==== enabled

Define if the virtual machine is considered highly available.
Configuring a VM lease is highly recommended (refer to that section) in order to
prevent split-brain scenarios. Use a boot disk's storage-domain or any other
active storage-domain.

[id="types/high_availability/attributes/priority"]
==== priority

Indicates the priority of the virtual machine inside the run and migration queues.

Virtual machines with higher priorities will be started and migrated before virtual machines with lower
priorities.

The value is an integer between 0 and 100. The higher the value, the higher the priority.

The graphical user interface (GUI) does not allow specifying all the possible values, instead
it only allows you to select _Low_, _Medium_ or _High_. When the value is set using the API, the GUI
will set the label as follows:

|===
|API Value |GUI Label

|0 - 25 |Low
|26 - 74 |Medium
|75 - 100 |High

|===

When the label is selected using the GUI, the value in the API will be set as follows:

|===
|GUI Label |API Value

|Low |1
|Medium |50
|High |100

|===

[id="types/hook"]
=== Hook [small]#struct#

Represents a hook.

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`comment`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Free text containing comments about this object.

|`description`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable description in plain text.

|`event_name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Name of the event to execute the hook on.

|`id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A unique identifier.

|`md5`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Checksum of the hook.

|`name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable name in plain text.

|===

.Links summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`host`
|<<types/host,Host>>
|Reference to the host the hook belongs to.

|===

[id="types/hook_content_type"]

|===

[id="types/hook_stage"]

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`post`
|Stage after start of volume.

|`pre`
|Stage before start of volume.

|===

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
