|Name |Summary

|`disabled`
|Hook is disabled.

|`enabled`
|Hook is enabled.

|`missing`
|Hook is missing.

|===

[id="types/host"]
=== Host [small]#struct#

Type representing a host.

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`address`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The host address (FQDN/IP).

|`auto_numa_status`
|<<types/auto_numa_status,AutoNumaStatus>>
|The host auto _non uniform memory access_ (NUMA) status.

|`certificate`
|<<types/certificate,Certificate>>
|The host certificate.

|`comment`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Free text containing comments about this object.

|`cpu`
|<<types/cpu,Cpu>>
|The CPU type of this host.

|`description`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable description in plain text.

|`device_passthrough`
|<<types/host_device_passthrough,HostDevicePassthrough>>
|Specifies whether host device passthrough is enabled on this host.

|`display`
|<<types/display,Display>>
|Optionally specify the display address of this host explicitly.

|`external_status`
|<<types/external_status,ExternalStatus>>
|The host external status.

|`hardware_information`
|<<types/hardware_information,HardwareInformation>>
|The host hardware information.

|`hosted_engine`
|<<types/hosted_engine,HostedEngine>>
|The self-hosted engine status of this host.

|`id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A unique identifier.

|`iscsi`
|<<types/iscsi_details,IscsiDetails>>
|The host iSCSI details.

|`kdump_status`
|<<types/kdump_status,KdumpStatus>>
|The host KDUMP status.

|`ksm`
|<<types/ksm,Ksm>>
|Kernel SamePage Merging (KSM) reduces references to memory pages from multiple identical pages to a single page
reference.

|`libvirt_version`
|<<types/version,Version>>
|The host libvirt version.

|`max_scheduling_memory`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|The max scheduling memory on this host in bytes.

|`memory`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|The amount of physical memory on this host in bytes.

|`name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable name in plain text.

|`network_operation_in_progress`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Specifies whether a network-related operation, such as 'setup networks',
'sync networks', or 'refresh capabilities', is currently being executed on this host.

|`numa_supported`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Specifies whether _non uniform memory access_ (NUMA) is supported on this host.

|`os`
|<<types/operating_system,OperatingSystem>>
|The operating system on this host.

|`override_iptables`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Specifies whether we should override firewall definitions.

|`port`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|The host port.

|`power_management`
|<<types/power_management,PowerManagement>>
|The host power management definitions.

|`protocol`
|<<types/host_protocol,HostProtocol>>
|The protocol that the engine uses to communicate with
the host.

|`root_password`
|<<types/string,String>>
|When creating a new host, a root password is required if the password authentication method is chosen,
but this is not subsequently included in the representation.

|`se_linux`
|<<types/se_linux,SeLinux>>
|The host SElinux status.

|`spm`
|<<types/spm,Spm>>
|The host _storage pool manager_ (SPM) status and definition.

|`ssh`
|<<types/ssh,Ssh>>
|The SSH definitions.

|`status`
|<<types/host_status,HostStatus>>
|The host status.

|`status_detail`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The host status details.

|`summary`
|<<types/vm_summary,VmSummary>>
|The virtual machine summary - how many are active, migrating and total.

|`transparent_huge_pages`
|<<types/transparent_huge_pages,TransparentHugePages>>
|Transparent huge page support expands the size of memory pages beyond the standard 4 KiB limit.

|`type`
|<<types/host_type,HostType>>
|Indicates if the host contains a full installation of the operating system or a scaled-down version intended
only to host virtual machines.

|`update_available`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Specifies whether there is an oVirt-related update on this host.

|`version`
|<<types/version,Version>>
|The version of VDSM.

|`vgpu_placement`
|<<types/vgpu_placement,VgpuPlacement>>
|Specifies the vGPU placement strategy.

|===

[id="types/host/attributes/external_status"]
==== external_status

The host external status.
This can be used by third-party software to change the host external status
in case of an issue.
This has no effect on the host lifecycle, unless a third-party software checks for this
status and acts accordingly.

[id="types/host/attributes/hosted_engine"]
==== hosted_engine

The self-hosted engine status of this host.

IMPORTANT: When a host or collection of hosts is retrieved, this attribute is not included unless the
`all_content` parameter of the operation is explicitly set to `true`. See the documentation of the
operations that retrieve <<services/host/methods/get/parameters/all_content, one>> or
<<services/hosts/methods/list/parameters/all_content, multiple>> hosts for details.

[id="types/host/attributes/kdump_status"]
==== kdump_status

The host KDUMP status.
KDUMP happens when the host kernel has crashed and it is now going through memory dumping.

[id="types/host/attributes/ksm"]
==== ksm

Kernel SamePage Merging (KSM) reduces references to memory pages from multiple identical pages to a single page
reference. This helps with optimization for memory density.

For example, to enable KSM for host `123`, send a request like this:

....
PUT /ovirt-engine/api/hosts/123
....

With a request body like this:

[source,xml]

<host> <ksm> <enabled>true</enabled> </ksm> </host>

[id="types/host/attributes/libvirt_version"]
==== libvirt_version

The host libvirt version.
For more information on libvirt please go to https://libvirt.org[libvirt].

[id="types/host/attributes/network_operation_in_progress"]
==== network_operation_in_progress

Specifies whether a network-related operation, such as 'setup networks',
'sync networks', or 'refresh capabilities', is currently being executed on this host.

NOTE: The header `All-Content:true` must be added to the request in order for this
attribute to be included in the response.

[id="types/host/attributes/override_iptables"]
==== override_iptables

Specifies whether we should override firewall definitions.
This applies only when the host is installed or re-installed.

[id="types/host/attributes/protocol"]
==== protocol

The protocol that the engine uses to communicate with
the host.

WARNING: Since version 4.1 of the engine the protocol
is always set to `stomp` since `xml` was removed.

[id="types/host/attributes/se_linux"]
==== se_linux

The host SElinux status.
_Security-Enhanced Linux (SELinux)_ is a component in the Linux kernel
that provides a mechanism for supporting access control security policies.

[id="types/host/attributes/spm"]
==== spm

The host _storage pool manager_ (SPM) status and definition.
Use it to set the SPM priority of this host, and to see whether this is the current
SPM or not.

[id="types/host/attributes/status_detail"]
==== status_detail

The host status details. Relevant for Gluster hosts.

[id="types/host/attributes/transparent_huge_pages"]
==== transparent_huge_pages

Transparent huge page support expands the size of memory pages beyond the standard 4 KiB limit. This reduces
memory consumption and increases host performance.

For example, to enable transparent huge page support for host `123`, send a request like this:

....
PUT /ovirt-engine/api/hosts/123
....

With a request body like this:

[source,xml]

<host> <transparent_hugepages> <enabled>true</enabled> </transparent_hugepages> </host>

[id="types/host/attributes/version"]
==== version

The version of VDSM.

For example:

[source]

GET /ovirt-engine/api/hosts/123

This `GET` request will return the following output:

[source,xml]

<host> …​ <version> <build>999</build> <full_version>vdsm-4.18.999-419.gitcf06367.el7</full_version> <major>4</major> <minor>18</minor> <revision>0</revision> </version> …​ </host>

.Links summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`affinity_labels`
|<<types/affinity_label,AffinityLabel[]>>
|

|`agents`
|<<types/agent,Agent[]>>
|

|`cluster`
|<<types/cluster,Cluster>>
|

|`devices`
|<<types/device,Device[]>>
|

|`external_host_provider`
|<<types/external_host_provider,ExternalHostProvider>>
|

|`external_network_provider_configurations`
|<<types/external_network_provider_configuration,ExternalNetworkProviderConfiguration[]>>
|External network providers provisioned on the host.

|`hooks`
|<<types/hook,Hook[]>>
|

|`katello_errata`
|<<types/katello_erratum,KatelloErratum[]>>
|Lists all the Katello errata assigned to the host.

|`network_attachments`
|<<types/network_attachment,NetworkAttachment[]>>
|

|`nics`
|<<types/host_nic,HostNic[]>>
|

|`numa_nodes`
|<<types/numa_node,NumaNode[]>>
|

|`permissions`
|<<types/permission,Permission[]>>
|

|`statistics`
|<<types/statistic,Statistic[]>>
|Each host resource exposes a statistics sub-collection for host-specific statistics.

|`storage_connection_extensions`
|<<types/storage_connection_extension,StorageConnectionExtension[]>>
|

|`storages`
|<<types/host_storage,HostStorage[]>>
|

|`tags`
|<<types/tag,Tag[]>>
|

|`unmanaged_networks`
|<<types/unmanaged_network,UnmanagedNetwork[]>>
|

|===

[id="types/host/links/external_network_provider_configurations"]
==== external_network_provider_configurations

External network providers provisioned on the host.

External network providers on the host can be controlled when <<services/hosts/methods/add,adding the host>>.

[id="types/host/links/katello_errata"]
==== katello_errata

Lists all the Katello errata assigned to the host.

[source]

GET /ovirt-engine/api/hosts/123/katelloerrata

You will receive response in XML like this one:

[source,xml]

<katello_errata> <katello_erratum href="/ovirt-engine/api/katelloerrata/456" id="456"> <name>RHBA-2013:XYZ</name> <description>The description of the erratum</description> <title>some bug fix update</title> <type>bugfix</type> <issued>2013-11-20T02:00:00.000+02:00</issued> <solution>Few guidelines regarding the solution</solution> <summary>Updated packages that fix one bug are now available for XYZ</summary> <packages> <package> <name>libipa_hbac-1.9.2-82.11.el6_4.i686</name> </package> …​ </packages> </katello_erratum> …​ </katello_errata>

[id="types/host/links/statistics"]
==== statistics

Each host resource exposes a statistics sub-collection for host-specific statistics.

An example of an XML representation:

[source,xml]

<statistics> <statistic href="/ovirt-engine/api/hosts/123/statistics/456" id="456"> <name>memory.total</name> <description>Total memory</description> <kind>gauge</kind> <type>integer</type> <unit>bytes</unit> <values> <value> <datum>25165824000</datum> </value> </values> <host href="/ovirt-engine/api/hosts/123" id="123"/> </statistic> …​ </statistics>

NOTE: This statistics sub-collection is read-only.

The following list shows the statistic types for hosts:

|===
|Name |Description

|`memory.total`
|Total memory in bytes on the host.

|`memory.used`
|Memory in bytes used on the host.

|`memory.free`
|Memory in bytes free on the host.

|`memory.shared`
|Memory in bytes shared on the host.

|`memory.buffers`
|I/O buffers in bytes.

|`memory.cached`
|OS caches in bytes.

|`swap.total`
|Total swap memory in bytes on the host.

|`swap.free`
|Swap memory in bytes free on the host.

|`swap.used`
|Swap memory in bytes used on the host.

|`swap.cached`
|Swap memory in bytes also cached in host's memory.

|`ksm.cpu.current`
|Percentage of CPU usage for Kernel SamePage Merging.

|`cpu.current.user`
|Percentage of CPU usage for user slice.

|`cpu.current.system`
|Percentage of CPU usage for system.

|`cpu.current.idle`
|Percentage of idle CPU usage.

|`cpu.load.avg.5m`
|CPU load average per five minutes.

|`boot.time`
|Boot time of the machine.
|===

[id="types/host_device"]

|A unique identifier.

|`iommu_group`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>

|`name`
|<<types/string,String>>

|`physical_function`

|`placeholder`

|`product`

[id="types/host_device/attributes/driver"]
==== driver

The name of the driver this device is bound to.

For example: `pcieport` or `uhci_hcd`.

.Links summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`host`
|<<types/host,Host>>

|`parent_device`

|===

[id="types/host_device_passthrough"]

[cols="20,20,60"]

|Name |Type |Summary

|`enabled`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|

|===

[id="types/host_nic"]
=== HostNic [small]#struct#

Represents a host NIC.

For example, the XML representation of a host NIC looks like this:

[source,xml]

<host_nic href="/ovirt-engine/api/hosts/123/nics/456" id="456"> <name>eth0</name> <boot_protocol>static</boot_protocol> <bridged>true</bridged> <custom_configuration>true</custom_configuration> <ip> <address>192.168.122.39</address> <gateway>192.168.122.1</gateway> <netmask>255.255.255.0</netmask> <version>v4</version> </ip> <ipv6> <gateway>::</gateway> <version>v6</version> </ipv6> <ipv6_boot_protocol>none</ipv6_boot_protocol> <mac> <address>52:54:00:0c:79:1d</address> </mac> <mtu>1500</mtu> <status>up</status> </host_nic>

A bonded interface is represented as a <<types/host_nic, HostNic>> object
containing the `bonding` and `slaves` attributes.

For example, the XML representation of a bonded host NIC looks like this:

[source,xml]

<host_nic href="/ovirt-engine/api/hosts/123/nics/456" id="456"> <name>bond0</name> <mac address="00:00:00:00:00:00"/> <ip> <address>192.168.122.39</address> <gateway>192.168.122.1</gateway> <netmask>255.255.255.0</netmask> <version>v4</version> </ip> <boot_protocol>dhcp</boot_protocol> <bonding> <options> <option> <name>mode</name> <value>4</value> <type>Dynamic link aggregation (802.3ad)</type> </option> <option> <name>miimon</name> <value>100</value> </option> </options> <slaves> <host_nic id="123"/> <host_nic id="456"/> </slaves> </bonding> <mtu>1500</mtu> <bridged>true</bridged> <custom_configuration>false</custom_configuration> </host_nic>

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`ad_aggregator_id`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|The `ad_aggregator_id` property of a bond or bond slave, for bonds in mode 4.

|`base_interface`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The base interface of the NIC.

|`bonding`
|<<types/bonding,Bonding>>
|The bonding parameters of the NIC.

|`boot_protocol`
|<<types/boot_protocol,BootProtocol>>
|The IPv4 boot protocol configuration of the NIC.

|`bridged`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Defines the bridged network status.

|`check_connectivity`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|

|`comment`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Free text containing comments about this object.

|`custom_configuration`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|

|`description`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable description in plain text.

|`id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A unique identifier.

|`ip`
|<<types/ip,Ip>>
|The IPv4 address of the NIC.

|`ipv6`
|<<types/ip,Ip>>
|The IPv6 address of the NIC.

|`ipv6_boot_protocol`
|<<types/boot_protocol,BootProtocol>>
|The IPv6 boot protocol configuration of the NIC.

|`mac`
|<<types/mac,Mac>>
|The MAC address of the NIC.

|`mtu`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|The maximum transmission unit for the interface.

|`name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable name in plain text.

|`override_configuration`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|

|`properties`
|<<types/property,Property[]>>
|

|`speed`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|

|`status`
|<<types/nic_status,NicStatus>>
|

|`virtual_functions_configuration`
|<<types/host_nic_virtual_functions_configuration,HostNicVirtualFunctionsConfiguration>>
|Describes the virtual functions configuration of a physical function NIC.

|`vlan`
|<<types/vlan,Vlan>>
|

|===

[id="types/host_nic/attributes/ad_aggregator_id"]
==== ad_aggregator_id

The `ad_aggregator_id` property of a bond or bond slave, for bonds in mode 4.
Bond mode 4 is the 802.3ad standard, also called dynamic link aggregation.
(See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Link_aggregation[Wikipedia] and
http://www.ieee802.org/3/hssg/public/apr07/frazier_01_0407.pdf[Presentation] for more information).
This is only valid for bonds in mode 4, or NICs which are part of a bond.
It is not present for bonds in other modes, or NICs which are not part of a bond in mode 4.
The `ad_aggregator_id` property indicates which of the bond slaves are active. The value of the
`ad_aggregator_id` of an active slave is the same as the value of the `ad_aggregator_id` property of the bond.
This parameter is read only. Setting it will have no effect on the bond/NIC.
It is retrieved from the `/sys/class/net/bondX/bonding/ad_aggregator` file for a bond, and the
`/sys/class/net/ensX/bonding_slave/ad_aggregator_id` file for a NIC.

[id="types/host_nic/attributes/bridged"]
==== bridged

Defines the bridged network status. Set to `true` for a bridged network
and `false` for a bridgeless network.

.Links summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`host`
|<<types/host,Host>>
|

|`network`
|<<types/network,Network>>
|A reference to the network to which the interface should be connected.

|`network_labels`
|<<types/network_label,NetworkLabel[]>>
|The labels that are applied to this NIC.

|`physical_function`
|<<types/host_nic,HostNic>>
|A reference to the physical function NIC of a SR-IOV virtual function NIC.

|`qos`
|<<types/qos,Qos>>
|A link to the quality-of-service configuration of the interface.

|`statistics`
|<<types/statistic,Statistic[]>>
|A link to the statistics of the NIC.

|===

[id="types/host_nic/links/network"]
==== network

A reference to the network to which the interface should be connected. A blank network ID is allowed.

[id="types/host_nic/links/statistics"]
==== statistics

A link to the statistics of the NIC.

The data types for HostNic statistical values:

* data.current.rx - The rate in bytes per second of data received.
* data.current.tx - The rate in bytes per second of data transmitted.
* data.current.rx.bps - The rate in bits per second of data received (since version 4.2).
* data.current.tx.bps - The rate in bits per second of data transmitted (since version 4.2).
* data.total.rx - Total received data.
* data.total.tx - Total transmitted data.
* errors.total.rx - Total errors from receiving data.
* errors.total.tx - Total errors from transmitting data.

[id="types/host_nic_virtual_functions_configuration"]
=== HostNicVirtualFunctionsConfiguration [small]#struct#

Describes the virtual functions configuration of an SR-IOV-enabled physical function NIC.

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`all_networks_allowed`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Defines whether all networks are allowed to be defined on the related virtual functions, or specified ones only.

|`max_number_of_virtual_functions`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|The maximum number of virtual functions the NIC supports.

|`number_of_virtual_functions`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|The number of virtual functions currently defined.

|===

[id="types/host_nic_virtual_functions_configuration/attributes/max_number_of_virtual_functions"]
==== max_number_of_virtual_functions

The maximum number of virtual functions the NIC supports. This property is read-only.

[id="types/host_nic_virtual_functions_configuration/attributes/number_of_virtual_functions"]
==== number_of_virtual_functions

The number of virtual functions currently defined. A user-defined value between 0 and
`max_number_of_virtual_functions`.

[id="types/host_protocol"]
=== HostProtocol [small]#enum#

The protocol used by the engine to communicate with
a host.

WARNING: Since version 4.1 of the engine the protocol
is always set to `stomp` since `xml` was removed.

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`stomp`
|JSON-RPC protocol on top of STOMP.

|`xml`
|XML-RPC protocol.

|===

[id="types/host_status"]
=== HostStatus [small]#enum#

Type representing a host status.

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`connecting`
|The engine cannot communicate with the host for a specific threshold
so it is now trying to connect before going through fencing.

|`down`
|The host is down.

|`error`
|The host is in error status.

|`initializing`
|The host is initializing.

|`install_failed`
|The host installation failed.

|`installing`
|The host is being installed.

|`installing_os`
|The host operating system is now installing.

|`kdumping`
|The host kernel has crashed and it is now going through memory dumping.

|`maintenance`
|The host is in maintenance status.

|`non_operational`
|The host is non operational.

|`non_responsive`
|The host is not responsive.

|`pending_approval`
|The host is pending administrator approval.

|`preparing_for_maintenance`
|The host is preparing for maintenance.

|`reboot`
|The host is being rebooted.

|`unassigned`
|The host is in activation process.

|`up`
|The host is up.

|===

[id="types/host_status/values/error"]
==== error

The host is in error status.
This will happen if we will try
to run a virtual machine several times and it
will fail.

[id="types/host_status/values/initializing"]
==== initializing

The host is initializing.
This is an intermediate step before
moving the host to 'up' status.

[id="types/host_status/values/install_failed"]
==== install_failed

The host installation failed.
In such cases look at the event log to understand
what failed the installation, and issue a re-install.

[id="types/host_status/values/installing_os"]
==== installing_os

The host operating system is now installing.
This status is relevant when using a Satellite/Foreman
provider, and issuing a bare-metal provisioning (discovered host provisioning).

[id="types/host_status/values/maintenance"]
==== maintenance

The host is in maintenance status.
When a host is in maintenance it cannot run virtual machines.

[id="types/host_status/values/non_operational"]
==== non_operational

The host is non operational.
This can happen due to various reasons, such as not having
a connection with the storage, not supporting a mandatory network,
not supporting the cluster level, and more.

[id="types/host_status/values/non_responsive"]
==== non_responsive

The host is not responsive.
This means that the engine is not able to communicate with the host.

[id="types/host_status/values/pending_approval"]
==== pending_approval

The host is pending administrator approval.
This is relevant only for vintage ovirt-node / RHV-H.

[id="types/host_status/values/preparing_for_maintenance"]
==== preparing_for_maintenance

The host is preparing for maintenance.
During this time the engine makes sure to live migrate
all the virtual machines from this host to other hosts.
Once all migrations have been completed the host will move
to 'maintenance' status.

[id="types/host_storage"]
=== HostStorage [small]#struct#

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`address`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`comment`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Free text containing comments about this object.

|`description`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable description in plain text.

|`driver_options`
|<<types/property,Property[]>>
|The options to be passed when creating a storage domain
using a cinder driver.

|`driver_sensitive_options`
|<<types/property,Property[]>>
|Parameters containing sensitive information, to be passed when creating a storage domain
using a cinder driver.

|`id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A unique identifier.

|`logical_units`
|<<types/logical_unit,LogicalUnit[]>>
|

|`mount_options`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable name in plain text.

|`nfs_retrans`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|The number of times to retry a request before attempting further recovery actions.

|`nfs_timeo`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|The time in tenths of a second to wait for a response before retrying NFS requests.

|`nfs_version`
|<<types/nfs_version,NfsVersion>>
|

|`override_luns`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|

|`password`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`path`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`port`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|

|`portal`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`target`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`type`
|<<types/storage_type,StorageType>>
|

|`username`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`vfs_type`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`volume_group`
|<<types/volume_group,VolumeGroup>>
|

|===

[id="types/host_storage/attributes/driver_options"]
==== driver_options

The options to be passed when creating a storage domain
using a cinder driver.


For example (Kaminario backend):
[source]

POST /ovirt-engine/api/storagedomains/

[source,xml]

<storage_domain> <name>kamniraio-cinder</name> <type>managed_block_storage</type> <storage> <type>managed_block_storage</type> <driver_options> <property> <name>san_ip</name> <value>192.168.1.1</value> </property> <property> <name>san_login</name> <value>username</value> </property> <property> <name>san_password</name> <value>password</value> </property> <property> <name>use_multipath_for_image_xfer</name> <value>true</value> </property> <property> <name>volume_driver</name> <value>cinder.volume.drivers.kaminario.kaminario_iscsi.KaminarioISCSIDriver</value> </property> </driver_options> </storage> <host> <name>host</name> </host> </storage_domain>

[id="types/host_storage/attributes/driver_sensitive_options"]
==== driver_sensitive_options

Parameters containing sensitive information, to be passed when creating a storage domain
using a cinder driver. These parameters are encrypted when they are saved.

For example, the following XML encrypts and saves a username, password and SAN IP address:

[source]

POST /ovirt-engine/api/storagedomains/

[source,xml]

<storage_domain> <name>kamniraio-cinder</name> <type>managed_block_storage</type> <storage> <type>managed_block_storage</type> <driver_options> <property> <name>san_ip</name> <value>192.168.1.1</value> </property> <property> <name>san_login</name> <value>username</value> </property> <property> <name>san_password</name> <value>password</value> </property> <property> <name>use_multipath_for_image_xfer</name> <value>true</value> </property> <property> <name>volume_driver</name> <value>cinder.volume.drivers.kaminario.kaminario_iscsi.KaminarioISCSIDriver</value> </property> </driver_options> <driver_sensitive_options> <property> <name>username</name> <value>admin</value> </property> <property> <name>password</name> <value>123</value> </property> <property> <name>san_ip</name> <value>192.168.1.1</value> </property> </driver_sensitive_options> </storage> <host> <name>host</name> </host> </storage_domain>

[id="types/host_storage/attributes/nfs_retrans"]
==== nfs_retrans

The number of times to retry a request before attempting further recovery actions. The value must be in the
range of 0 to 65535. For more details see the description of the `retrans` mount option in the `nfs` man page.

[id="types/host_storage/attributes/nfs_timeo"]
==== nfs_timeo

The time in tenths of a second to wait for a response before retrying NFS requests. The value must be in the
range of 0 to 65535. For more details see the description of the `timeo` mount option in the `nfs` man page.

.Links summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`host`
|<<types/host,Host>>
|

|===

[id="types/host_type"]
=== HostType [small]#enum#

This enumerated type is used to determine which type of operating system is used by the host.

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`ovirt_node`
|The host contains Red Hat Virtualization Host (RHVH): a new implementation of
Red Hat Enterprise Virtualization Hypervisor (RHEV-H) which uses the same installer as Red Hat Enterprise Linux,
CentOS, or Fedora.

|`rhel`
|The host contains a full Red Hat Enterprise Linux, CentOS, or Fedora installation.

|`rhev_h`
|The host contains Red Hat Enterprise Virtualization Hypervisor (RHEV-H), a small-scaled version of Red Hat
Enterprise Linux, CentOS, or Fedora, used solely to host virtual machines.

|===

[id="types/host_type/values/ovirt_node"]
==== ovirt_node

The host contains Red Hat Virtualization Host (RHVH): a new implementation of
Red Hat Enterprise Virtualization Hypervisor (RHEV-H) which uses the same installer as Red Hat Enterprise Linux,
CentOS, or Fedora. The main difference between RHVH and legacy RHEV-H is that RHVH has a writeable file system
and will handle its own installation instead of having RPMs pushed to it by the Manager like in legacy RHEV-H.

|

|===

[id="types/icon"]
=== Icon [small]#struct#

Icon of virtual machine or template.

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`comment`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Free text containing comments about this object.

|`data`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Base64 encode content of the icon file.

|`description`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable description in plain text.

|`id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A unique identifier.

|`media_type`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Format of icon file.

|`name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable name in plain text.

|===

[id="types/icon/attributes/media_type"]
==== media_type

Format of icon file.

One of:

* `image/jpeg`
* `image/png`
* `image/gif`

[id="types/image"]

[id="types/image_file_type"]
=== ImageFileType [small]#enum#

Represents the file type of an image.

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`disk`
|The image is a disk format that can be used as a virtual machine's disk.

|`floppy`
|The image is a floppy disk that can be attached to a virtual machine,
for example to install the VirtIO drivers in Windows.

|`iso`
|The image is a `.

|===

[id="types/image_file_type/values/iso"]
==== iso

The image is a `.iso` file that can be used as a CD-ROM
to boot and install a virtual machine.

[id="types/image_transfer"]
=== ImageTransfer [small]#struct#

This type contains information regarding an image transfer being performed.

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`active`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Indicates whether there's at least one active session for this transfer, i,e
there's at least one live transfer session between the client and the daemon.

|`comment`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Free text containing comments about this object.

|`description`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable description in plain text.

|`direction`
|<<types/image_transfer_direction,ImageTransferDirection>>
|The direction indicates whether the transfer is sending image data (`upload`) or
receiving image data (`download`).

|`format`
|<<types/disk_format,DiskFormat>>
|The format of the data sent during upload or received during download.

|`id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A unique identifier.

|`inactivity_timeout`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|The timeout in seconds of client inactivity, after which the transfer is aborted by the {engine-name}.

|`name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable name in plain text.

|`phase`
|<<types/image_transfer_phase,ImageTransferPhase>>
|The current phase of the image transfer in progress.

|`proxy_url`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The URL of the proxy server that the user inputs or outputs to.

|`signed_ticket`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The signed ticket that should be attached as an `Authentication` header in the
HTTPS request for the proxy server to input or output to (See the `proxy_url` attribute).

|`transfer_url`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The URL of the daemon server that the user can input or output to directly.

|`transferred`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|Indicates the amount of transferred bytes.

|===

[id="types/image_transfer/attributes/direction"]
==== direction

The direction indicates whether the transfer is sending image data (`upload`) or
receiving image data (`download`).

If a direction is not set during an addition of a new transfer,
The default direction for the transfer will be `upload`.

[id="types/image_transfer/attributes/format"]
==== format

The format of the data sent during upload or received during download.
If not specified, defaults to disk's format.

[id="types/image_transfer/attributes/inactivity_timeout"]
==== inactivity_timeout

The timeout in seconds of client inactivity, after which the transfer is aborted by the {engine-name}.
To disable the inactivity timeout specify '0'. If not specified, the value is defaulted to the
`engine-config` value: TransferImageClientInactivityTimeoutInSeconds.

[id="types/image_transfer/attributes/phase"]
==== phase

The current phase of the image transfer in progress. Each transfer needs a managed
session, which must be opened for the user to input or output an image.
Please refer to <<services/image_transfer, image transfer>> for further
documentation.

[id="types/image_transfer/attributes/proxy_url"]
==== proxy_url

The URL of the proxy server that the user inputs or outputs to. This attribute is
available only if the image transfer is in the <<types/image_transfer_phase, transferring>>
phase. See `phase` for details.

[id="types/image_transfer/attributes/transfer_url"]
==== transfer_url

The URL of the daemon server that the user can input or output to directly.

This is as an alternative to the `proxy_url`. I.e. if the client has access to the host machine, it could bypass
the proxy and transfer directly to the host, potentially improving the throughput performance. This attribute is
available only if the image transfer is in the <<types/image_transfer_phase, transferring>>
phase. See `phase` for details.

.Links summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`backup`
|<<types/backup,Backup>>
|The backup associated with the image transfer.

|`disk`
|<<types/disk,Disk>>
|The disk which is targeted for input or output.

|`host`
|<<types/host,Host>>
|The host which will be used to write to the image which is targeted for input or output.

|`image`
|<<types/image,Image>>
|The image which is targeted for input or output.

|`snapshot`
|<<types/disk_snapshot,DiskSnapshot>>
|The disk snapshot which is targeted for input or output.

|===

[id="types/image_transfer/links/backup"]
==== backup

The backup associated with the image transfer.
Specify when initiating an image transfer for a disk that is part of a backup.

[id="types/image_transfer/links/host"]
==== host

The host which will be used to write to the image which is targeted for input or output.
If not specified, an active host will be randomly selected from the data center.

[id="types/image_transfer/links/image"]
==== image

The image which is targeted for input or output.

IMPORTANT: This attribute is deprecated since version
4.2 of the engine. Use the `disk` or `snapshot`
attributes instead.

[id="types/image_transfer_direction"]
=== ImageTransferDirection [small]#enum#

The <<types/image_transfer, image transfer>> direction for a transfer.

When adding a new transfer, the user can choose whether the transfer will be to an image, choosing `upload`,
or to transfer from an image- choosing `download` as an ImageTransferDirection.

Please refer to <<services/image_transfer, image transfer>> for further
documentation.

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`download`
|The user must choose `download` when he/she wants to stream data from an image.

|`upload`
|The user can choose `upload` when he/she wants to stream data to an image.

|===

[id="types/image_transfer_phase"]
=== ImageTransferPhase [small]#enum#

A list of possible phases for an <<types/image_transfer, image transfer>> entity. Each of these values
defines a specific point in a transfer flow.

Please refer to <<services/image_transfer, image transfer>> for more
information.

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`cancelled`
|This phase will be set as a result of the user cancelling the transfer.

|`cancelled_system`
|This phase will be set as a result of the system cancelling the transfer.

|`cancelled_user`
|This phase will be set as a result of the user cancelling the transfer.

|`finalizing_cleanup`
|This phase indicates that the user cancelled the transfer, and necessary cleanup is being done.

|`finalizing_failure`
|This phase can only be set in the Administration Portal, and indicates that there was an error during the transfer, and it
is being finalized with a failure.

|`finalizing_success`
|This phase will be set when the user calls <<services/image_transfer/methods/finalize, finalize>>.

|`finished_cleanup`
|This phase indicates that the user cancelled the transfer, and necessary cleanup is done.

|`finished_failure`
|Indicates that the targeted image failed the verification, and cannot be used.

|`finished_success`
|Indicates that the transfer session was successfully closed, and the targeted image was verified and ready to be
used.

|`initializing`
|The initial phase of an image transfer.

|`paused_system`
|This phase means the session timed out, or some other error occurred
with this transfer; for example ovirt-imageio-daemon is not running in the selected host.

|`paused_user`
|This phase is a result of a pause call by the user, using
<<services/image_transfer/methods/pause, pause>>.

|`resuming`
|The phase where the transfer has been resumed by the client calling
<<services/image_transfer/methods/resume, resume>>.

|`transferring`
|The phase where the transfer session is open, and the client can input or output the desired image using the preferred
tools.

|`unknown`
|An unknown phase.

|===

[id="types/image_transfer_phase/values/cancelled"]
==== cancelled

This phase will be set as a result of the user cancelling the transfer. The cancellation can only be performed
in the Administration Portal.

[id="types/image_transfer_phase/values/finalizing_success"]
==== finalizing_success

This phase will be set when the user calls <<services/image_transfer/methods/finalize, finalize>>. Calling
finalize is essential to finish the transfer session, and finish using the targeted image. After finalizing,
the phase will be changed to `finished_success` or `finished_failure`.

Refer to <<services/image_transfer, image transfer>> for more information.

[id="types/image_transfer_phase/values/finished_failure"]
==== finished_failure

Indicates that the targeted image failed the verification, and cannot be used. After reaching this phase,
the image transfer entity will be deleted, and the targeted image will be set to illegal. System cancelling the
transfer will also result in this.

[id="types/image_transfer_phase/values/finished_success"]
==== finished_success

Indicates that the transfer session was successfully closed, and the targeted image was verified and ready to be
used. After reaching this phase, the image transfer entity will be deleted.

[id="types/image_transfer_phase/values/initializing"]
==== initializing

The initial phase of an image transfer. It is set while the transfer session is establishing.
Once the session is established, the phase will be changed to `transferring`

[id="types/image_transfer_phase/values/paused_system"]
==== paused_system

This phase means the session timed out, or some other error occurred
with this transfer; for example ovirt-imageio-daemon is not running in the selected host.
To resume the session, the client should call <<services/image_transfer/methods/resume, resume>>. After
resuming, the phase will change to `resuming`.

[id="types/image_transfer_phase/values/resuming"]
==== resuming

The phase where the transfer has been resumed by the client calling
<<services/image_transfer/methods/resume, resume>>. Resuming starts a new session, and after calling it,
the phase will be changed to `transferring`, or `paused_system` in case of a failure.

[id="types/image_transfer_phase/values/unknown"]
==== unknown

An unknown phase. This will only be set in cases of unpredictable errors.

[id="types/inheritable_boolean"]
=== InheritableBoolean [small]#enum#

Enum representing the boolean value that can be either set, or inherited from a higher level.
The inheritance order is virtual machine -> cluster -> engine-config.

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`false`
|Set the value to false on this level.

|`inherit`
|Inherit the value from higher level.

|`true`
|Set the value to true on this level.

|===

[id="types/initialization"]
=== Initialization [small]#struct#

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`active_directory_ou`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`authorized_ssh_keys`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`cloud_init`
|<<types/cloud_init,CloudInit>>
|Deprecated attribute to specify _cloud-init_ configuration.

|`cloud_init_network_protocol`
|<<types/cloud_init_network_protocol,CloudInitNetworkProtocol>>
|Attribute specifying the cloud-init protocol to
use for formatting the cloud-init network parameters.

|`configuration`
|<<types/configuration,Configuration>>
|

|`custom_script`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`dns_search`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`dns_servers`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`domain`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`host_name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`input_locale`
|<<types/string,String>>

|`nic_configurations`
|<<types/nic_configuration,NicConfiguration[]>>
|

|`org_name`
|<<types/string,String>>

|`regenerate_ids`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|

|`regenerate_ssh_keys`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|

|`root_password`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`system_locale`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`timezone`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`ui_language`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`user_locale`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`user_name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`windows_license_key`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|===

[id="types/initialization/attributes/cloud_init"]
==== cloud_init

Deprecated attribute to specify _cloud-init_ configuration.

This attribute, and the <<types/cloud_init, CloudInit>> type have been deprecated and will be
removed in the future.  To specify the _cloud-init_ configuration, use the attributes inside
the <<types/initialization, Initialization>> type. The mapping between the attributes
of these two types are as follows:

|===
|CloudInit |Initialization

|`authorized_keys` |`authorized_ssh_keys`
|`dns.search_domains` |`dns_search`
|`dns.servers` |`dns_servers`
|`files` |`custom_script`
|`host` |`host_name`
|`network_configuration.nics` |`nic_configurations`
|`regenerate_ssh_keys` |`regenerate_ssh_keys`
|`timezone` |`timezone`
|`users` |`user_name` & `root_password`

|===

For more details on how to use _cloud-init_ see the examples in
https://github.com/oVirt/ovirt-engine-sdk/blob/master/sdk/examples/start_vm_with_cloud_init.py[Python],
https://github.com/oVirt/ovirt-engine-sdk-ruby/blob/master/sdk/examples/start_vm_with_cloud_init.rb[Ruby] and
https://github.com/oVirt/ovirt-engine-sdk-java/blob/master/sdk/src/test/java/org/ovirt/engine/sdk4/examples/StartVmWithCloudInit.java[Java].

[id="types/initialization/attributes/cloud_init_network_protocol"]
==== cloud_init_network_protocol

Attribute specifying the cloud-init protocol to
use for formatting the cloud-init network parameters.
If omitted, a default value is used, as described in
the <<types/cloud_init_network_protocol, CloudInitNetworkProtocol>>

[id="types/instance_type"]
=== InstanceType [small]#struct#

Describes the hardware configuration of virtual machines.

For example `medium` instance type includes 1 virtual CPU and 4 GiB of memory. It is a top-level
entity (e.g. not bound to any data center or cluster). The attributes that are used for instance
types and are common to virtual machine and template types are:

- `console`
- `cpu`
- `custom_cpu_model`
- `custom_emulated_machine`
- `display`
- `high_availability`
- `io`
- `memory`
- `memory_policy`
- `migration`
- `migration_downtime`
- `os`
- `rng_device`
- `soundcard_enabled`
- `usb`
- `virtio_scsi`

When creating a virtual machine from both an instance type and a template, the virtual machine
will inherit the hardware configurations from the instance type

NOTE: An instance type inherits it's attributes from the template entity although most template
attributes are not used in instance types.

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`bios`
|<<types/bios,Bios>>
|Reference to virtual machine's BIOS configuration.

|`comment`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Free text containing comments about this object.

|`console`
|<<types/console,Console>>
|Console configured for this virtual machine.

|`cpu`
|<<types/cpu,Cpu>>
|The configuration of the virtual machine CPU.

|`cpu_shares`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|

|`creation_time`
|<<types/date,Date>>
|The virtual machine creation date.

|`custom_compatibility_version`
|<<types/version,Version>>
|Virtual machine custom compatibility version.

|`custom_cpu_model`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`custom_emulated_machine`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`custom_properties`
|<<types/custom_property,CustomProperty[]>>
|Properties sent to VDSM to configure various hooks.

|`delete_protected`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|If `true`, the virtual machine cannot be deleted.

|`description`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable description in plain text.

|`display`
|<<types/display,Display>>
|The virtual machine display configuration.

|`domain`
|<<types/domain,Domain>>
|Domain configured for this virtual machine.

|`high_availability`
|<<types/high_availability,HighAvailability>>
|The virtual machine high availability configuration.

|`id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A unique identifier.

|`initialization`
|<<types/initialization,Initialization>>
|Reference to the virtual machine's initialization configuration.

|`io`
|<<types/io,Io>>
|For performance tuning of IO threading.

|`large_icon`
|<<types/icon,Icon>>
|Virtual machine's large icon.

|`lease`
|<<types/storage_domain_lease,StorageDomainLease>>
|Reference to the storage domain this virtual machine/template lease reside on.

|`memory`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|The virtual machine's memory, in bytes.

|`memory_policy`
|<<types/memory_policy,MemoryPolicy>>
|Reference to virtual machine's memory management configuration.

|`migration`
|<<types/migration_options,MigrationOptions>>
|Reference to configuration of migration of running virtual machine to another host.

|`migration_downtime`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|Maximum time the virtual machine can be non responsive during its live migration to another host in ms.

|`multi_queues_enabled`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|If `true`, each virtual interface will get the optimal number of queues, depending on the available virtual Cpus.

|`name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable name in plain text.

|`origin`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The origin of this virtual machine.

|`os`
|<<types/operating_system,OperatingSystem>>
|Operating system type installed on the virtual machine.

|`placement_policy`
|<<types/vm_placement_policy,VmPlacementPolicy>>
|The configuration of the virtual machine's placement policy.

|`rng_device`
|<<types/rng_device,RngDevice>>
|Random Number Generator device configuration for this virtual machine.

|`serial_number`
|<<types/serial_number,SerialNumber>>
|Virtual machine's serial number in a cluster.

|`small_icon`
|<<types/icon,Icon>>
|Virtual machine's small icon.

|`soundcard_enabled`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|If `true`, the sound card is added to the virtual machine.

|`sso`
|<<types/sso,Sso>>
|Reference to the Single Sign On configuration this virtual machine is configured for.

|`start_paused`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|If `true`, the virtual machine will be initially in 'paused' state after start.

|`stateless`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|If `true`, the virtual machine is stateless - it's state (disks) are rolled-back after shutdown.

|`status`
|<<types/template_status,TemplateStatus>>
|The status of the template.

|`storage_error_resume_behaviour`
|<<types/vm_storage_error_resume_behaviour,VmStorageErrorResumeBehaviour>>
|Determines how the virtual machine will be resumed after storage error.

|`time_zone`
|<<types/time_zone,TimeZone>>
|The virtual machine's time zone set by oVirt.

|`tunnel_migration`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|If `true`, the network data transfer will be encrypted during virtual machine live migration.

|`type`
|<<types/vm_type,VmType>>
|Determines whether the virtual machine is optimized for desktop or server.

|`usb`
|<<types/usb,Usb>>
|Configuration of USB devices for this virtual machine (count, type).

|`version`
|<<types/template_version,TemplateVersion>>
|Indicates whether this is the base version or a sub-version of another template.

|`virtio_scsi`
|<<types/virtio_scsi,VirtioScsi>>
|Reference to VirtIO SCSI configuration.

|`vm`
|<<types/vm,Vm>>
|The virtual machine configuration associated with this template.

|===

[id="types/instance_type/attributes/cpu"]
==== cpu

The configuration of the virtual machine CPU.

The socket configuration can be updated without rebooting the virtual machine. The cores and the threads require
a reboot.

For example, to change the number of sockets to 4 immediately, and the number of cores and threads to 2 after
reboot, send the following request:

[source]

PUT /ovirt-engine/api/vms/123

With a request body:

[source,xml]

<vm> <cpu> <topology> <sockets>4</sockets> <cores>2</cores> <threads>2</threads> </topology> </cpu> </vm>

[id="types/instance_type/attributes/custom_compatibility_version"]
==== custom_compatibility_version

Virtual machine custom compatibility version.

Enables a virtual machine to be customized to its own compatibility version.  If
`custom_compatibility_version` is set, it overrides the cluster's compatibility version
for this particular virtual machine.

The compatibility version of a virtual machine is limited by the data center the virtual
machine resides in, and is checked against capabilities of the host the virtual machine is
planned to run on.

[id="types/instance_type/attributes/high_availability"]
==== high_availability

The virtual machine high availability configuration.
If set, the virtual machine will be automatically restarted when it unexpectedly goes down.

[id="types/instance_type/attributes/initialization"]
==== initialization

Reference to the virtual machine's initialization configuration.

NOTE: Since {product-name} 4.1.8 this property can be cleared by sending an empty tag.

For example, to clear the `initialization` attribute send a request like this:

[source]

PUT /ovirt-engine/api/vms/123

With a request body like this:

[source,xml]

<vm> <initialization/> </vm>

The response to such a request, and requests with the header `All-Content: true` will still contain this attribute.

[id="types/instance_type/attributes/large_icon"]
==== large_icon

Virtual machine's large icon. Either set by user or refers to image set according to operating system.

[id="types/instance_type/attributes/lease"]
==== lease

Reference to the storage domain this virtual machine/template lease reside on.

A virtual machine running with a lease requires checking while running that the lease is not taken by another
host, preventing another instance of this virtual machine from running on another host.
This provides protection against split-brain in highly available virtual machines.
A template can also have a storage domain defined for a lease in order to have the virtual machines created
from this template to be preconfigured with this storage domain as the location of the leases.

[id="types/instance_type/attributes/memory"]
==== memory

The virtual machine's memory, in bytes.

For example, to update a virtual machine to contain 1 Gibibyte (GiB) of memory, send the following request:

[source]

PUT /ovirt-engine/api/vms/123

With the following request body:

[source,xml]

<vm> <memory>1073741824</memory> </vm>

Memory hot plug is supported from {product-name} 3.6 onwards. You can use the example above to increase
memory while the virtual machine is in state <<types/vm_status/values/up, up>>. The size increment must be
dividable by the value of the `HotPlugMemoryBlockSizeMb` configuration value (256 MiB by default). If the memory
size increment is not dividable by this value, the memory size change is only stored to next run configuration.
Each successful memory hot plug operation creates one or two new memory devices.

Memory hot unplug is supported since {product-name} 4.2 onwards. Memory hot unplug can only be performed
when the virtual machine is in state <<types/vm_status/values/up, up>>. Only previously hot plugged memory
devices can be removed by the hot unplug operation. The requested memory decrement is rounded down to match sizes
of a combination of previously hot plugged memory devices. The requested memory value is stored to next run
configuration without rounding.

NOTE: Memory in the example is converted to bytes using the following formula: +
1 GiB = 2^30^ bytes = 1073741824 bytes.

NOTE: {engine-name} internally rounds values down to whole MiBs (1MiB = 2^20^ bytes)

[id="types/instance_type/attributes/migration_downtime"]
==== migration_downtime

Maximum time the virtual machine can be non responsive during its live migration to another host in ms.

Set either explicitly for the virtual machine or by `engine-config -s DefaultMaximumMigrationDowntime=[value]`

[id="types/instance_type/attributes/origin"]
==== origin

The origin of this virtual machine.

Possible values:

- `ovirt`
- `rhev`
- `vmware`
- `xen`
- `external`
- `hosted_engine`
- `managed_hosted_engine`
- `kvm`
- `physical_machine`
- `hyperv`

[id="types/instance_type/attributes/placement_policy"]
==== placement_policy

The configuration of the virtual machine's placement policy.

This configuration can be updated to pin a virtual machine to one or more hosts.

NOTE: Virtual machines that are pinned to multiple hosts cannot be live migrated, but in the event of a host
failure, any virtual machine configured to be highly available is automatically restarted on one of the other
hosts to which the virtual machine is pinned.

For example, to pin a virtual machine to two hosts, send the following request:

[source]

PUT /api/vms/123

With a request body like this:

[source,xml]

<vm> <high_availability> <enabled>true</enabled> <priority>1</priority> </high_availability> <placement_policy> <hosts> <host> <name>Host1</name> </host> <host> <name>Host2</name> </host> </hosts> <affinity>pinned</affinity> </placement_policy> </vm>

[id="types/instance_type/attributes/small_icon"]
==== small_icon

Virtual machine's small icon. Either set by user or refers to image set according to operating system.

[id="types/instance_type/attributes/sso"]
==== sso

Reference to the Single Sign On configuration this virtual machine is configured for.
The user can be automatically signed in the virtual machine's operating system when console is opened.

.Links summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`cdroms`
|<<types/cdrom,Cdrom[]>>
|Reference to the CD-ROM devices attached to the template.

|`cluster`
|<<types/cluster,Cluster>>
|Reference to cluster the virtual machine belongs to.

|`cpu_profile`
|<<types/cpu_profile,CpuProfile>>
|Reference to CPU profile used by this virtual machine.

|`disk_attachments`
|<<types/disk_attachment,DiskAttachment[]>>
|Reference to the disks attached to the template.

|`graphics_consoles`
|<<types/graphics_console,GraphicsConsole[]>>
|Reference to the graphic consoles attached to the template.

|`nics`
|<<types/nic,Nic[]>>
|Reference to the network interfaces attached to the template.

|`permissions`
|<<types/permission,Permission[]>>
|Reference to the user permissions attached to the template.

|`quota`
|<<types/quota,Quota>>
|Reference to quota configuration set for this virtual machine.

|`storage_domain`
|<<types/storage_domain,StorageDomain>>
|Reference to storage domain the virtual machine belongs to.

|`tags`
|<<types/tag,Tag[]>>
|Reference to the tags attached to the template.

|`watchdogs`
|<<types/watchdog,Watchdog[]>>
|Reference to the watchdog devices attached to the template.

|===

[id="types/io"]

|<<types/integer,Integer>>

[id="types/ip"]
=== Ip [small]#struct#

Represents the IP configuration of a network interface.

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`address`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The text representation of the IP address.

|`gateway`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The address of the default gateway.

|`netmask`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The network mask.

|`version`
|<<types/ip_version,IpVersion>>
|The version of the IP protocol.

|===

[id="types/ip/attributes/address"]
==== address

The text representation of the IP address.

For example, an IPv4 address will be represented as follows:

[source,xml]

<ip> <address>192.168.0.1</address> …​ </ip>

An IPv6 address will be represented as follows:

[source,xml]

<ip> <address>2620:52:0:20f0:4216:7eff:feaa:1b50</address> …​ </ip>

[id="types/ip/attributes/netmask"]
==== netmask

The network mask.

For IPv6 addresses the value is an integer in the range of 0-128, which represents the subnet prefix.

[id="types/ip/attributes/version"]
==== version

The version of the IP protocol.

NOTE: From version 4.1 of the Manager this attribute will be optional, and when a value is not provided, it will
be inferred from the value of the `address` attribute.

[id="types/ip_address_assignment"]
=== IpAddressAssignment [small]#struct#

Represents an IP address assignment for a network device.

For a static boot protocol assignment, subnet mask and IP address
(and optinally default gateway) must be provided in the IP configuration.

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`assignment_method`
|<<types/boot_protocol,BootProtocol>>
|Sets the boot protocol used to assign the IP configuration for a network device.

|`ip`
|<<types/ip,Ip>>
|Sets the IP configuration for a network device.

|===

[id="types/ip_version"]
=== IpVersion [small]#enum#

Defines the values for the IP protocol version.

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`v4`
|IPv4.

|`v6`
|IPv6.

|===

[id="types/job"]
=== Job [small]#struct#

Represents a job, which monitors execution of a flow in the system.
A job can contain multiple steps in a hierarchic structure.
The steps can be processed in parallel, depends on the implementation of the flow.

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`auto_cleared`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Indicates if the job should be cleared automatically after it was completed by the system.

|`comment`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Free text containing comments about this object.

|`description`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable description in plain text.

|`end_time`
|<<types/date,Date>>
|The end time of the job.

|`external`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Indicates if the job is originated by an external system.

|`id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A unique identifier.

|`last_updated`
|<<types/date,Date>>
|The last update date of the job.

|`name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable name in plain text.

|`start_time`
|<<types/date,Date>>
|The start time of the job.

|`status`
|<<types/job_status,JobStatus>>
|The status of the job.

|===

[id="types/job/attributes/external"]
==== external

Indicates if the job is originated by an external system.
External jobs are managed externally, by the creator of the job.

.Links summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`owner`
|<<types/user,User>>
|The user who is the owner of the job.

|`steps`
|<<types/step,Step[]>>
|The steps of the job.

|===

[id="types/job_status"]
=== JobStatus [small]#enum#

Represents the status of the job.

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`aborted`
|The aborted job status.

|`failed`
|The failed job status.

|`finished`
|The finished job status.

|`started`
|The started job status.

|`unknown`
|The unknown job status.

|===

[id="types/job_status/values/aborted"]
==== aborted

The aborted job status.
This status is applicable for an external job that was forcibly aborted.

[id="types/job_status/values/finished"]
==== finished

The finished job status.
This status describes a completed job execution.

[id="types/job_status/values/started"]
==== started

The started job status.
This status represents a job which is currently being executed.

[id="types/job_status/values/unknown"]
==== unknown

The unknown job status.
This status represents jobs which their resolution is not known, i.e. jobs that were executed before
the system was unexpectedly restarted.

[id="types/katello_erratum"]
=== KatelloErratum [small]#struct#

Type representing a Katello erratum.

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`comment`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Free text containing comments about this object.

|`description`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable description in plain text.

|`id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A unique identifier.

|`issued`
|<<types/date,Date>>
|The date when the Katello erratum was issued.

|`name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable name in plain text.

|`packages`
|<<types/package,Package[]>>
|The list of packages which solve the issue reported by the Katello erratum.

|`severity`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The severity of the Katello erratum.

|`solution`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The solution for the issue described by the Katello erratum.

|`summary`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The summary of the Katello erratum.

|`title`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The title of the Katello erratum.

|`type`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The type of the Katello erratum.

|===

[id="types/katello_erratum/attributes/severity"]
==== severity

The severity of the Katello erratum.

The supported severities are `moderate`, `important` or `critical`.

[id="types/katello_erratum/attributes/type"]
==== type

The type of the Katello erratum.

The supported types are `bugfix`, `enhancement` or `security`.

.Links summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`host`
|<<types/host,Host>>
|Reference to the host that the Katello erratum is assigned to.

|`vm`
|<<types/vm,Vm>>
|Reference to the virtual machine that the Katello erratum is assigned to.

[id="types/link_layer_discovery_protocol_element"]
=== LinkLayerDiscoveryProtocolElement [small]#struct#

Represents an information element received by Link Layer Discovery Protocol (LLDP).
IEEE 802.1AB defines type, length, value (TLV) as a "short, variable length encoding of an information element".
This type represents such an information element.

The attribute `name` is a human-readable string used to describe what the value is about, and may not be unique.
The name is redundant, because it could be created from `type` and the optional `oui` and `subtype`.
The purpose of `name` is to simplify the reading of the information element.
The `name` of a property is exactly the same string which is used in IEEE 802.1AB chapter 8.

Organizationally-specific information elements have the `type` of `127` and the attributes
`oui` and `subtype`.

For example, the XML representation of an information element may look like this:

[source,xml]

<link_layer_discovery_protocol_element> <name>Port VLAN Id</name> <oui>32962</oui> <properties> <property> <name>vlan id</name> <value>488</value> </property> <property> <name>vlan name</name> <value>v2-0488-03-0505</value> </property> </properties> <subtype>3</subtype> <type>127</type> </link_layer_discovery_protocol_element>

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`comment`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Free text containing comments about this object.

|`description`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable description in plain text.

|`id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A unique identifier.

|`name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable name in plain text.

|`oui`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|The organizationally-unique identifier (OUI) encoded as an integer.

|`properties`
|<<types/property,Property[]>>
|Represents structured data transported by the information element as a
list of name/value pairs.

|`subtype`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|The organizationally-defined subtype encoded as an integer.

|`type`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|The type of the LinkLayerDiscoveryProtocolElement encoded as an integer.

|===

[id="types/link_layer_discovery_protocol_element/attributes/oui"]
==== oui

The organizationally-unique identifier (OUI) encoded as an integer.
Only available if `type` is `127`.

[id="types/link_layer_discovery_protocol_element/attributes/subtype"]
==== subtype

The organizationally-defined subtype encoded as an integer.
Only available if `type` is `127`.

[id="types/log_max_memory_used_threshold_type"]
=== LogMaxMemoryUsedThresholdType [small]#enum#

Describes all maximum memory threshold types supported by the system.

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`absolute_value_in_mb`
|Absolute value threshold type.

|`percentage`
|Percentage threshold type.

|===

[id="types/log_max_memory_used_threshold_type/values/absolute_value_in_mb"]
==== absolute_value_in_mb

Absolute value threshold type.

When an absolute value is specified, an audit log event is logged if the free memory in MB falls below the value
specified in `LogMaxMemoryUsedThreshold`.

[id="types/log_max_memory_used_threshold_type/values/percentage"]
==== percentage

Percentage threshold type.

When a percentage is specified, an audit log event is logged if the memory used is above the value specified
in `LogMaxMemoryUsedThreshold`.

[id="types/log_severity"]
=== LogSeverity [small]#enum#

Enum representing a severity of an event.

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`alert`
|Alert severity.

|`error`
|Error severity.

|`normal`
|Normal severity.

|`warning`
|Warning severity.

|===

[id="types/log_severity/values/alert"]
==== alert

Alert severity.
Used to specify a condition that requires
an immediate attention.

[id="types/log_severity/values/error"]
==== error

Error severity.
Used to specify that there is an error that needs
to be examined.

[id="types/log_severity/values/normal"]
==== normal

Normal severity.
Used for information events.

[id="types/log_severity/values/warning"]
==== warning

Warning severity.
Used to warn something might be wrong.

[id="types/logical_unit"]
=== LogicalUnit [small]#struct#

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`address`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`discard_max_size`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|The maximum number of bytes that can be discarded by the logical unit's
underlying storage in a single operation.

|`discard_zeroes_data`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|True, if previously discarded blocks in the logical
unit's underlying storage are read back as zeros.

|`disk_id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`lun_mapping`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|

|`password`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`paths`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|

|`port`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|

|`portal`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`product_id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`serial`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`size`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|

|`status`
|<<types/lun_status,LunStatus>>
|

|`storage_domain_id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`target`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`username`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`vendor_id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`volume_group_id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|===

[id="types/logical_unit/attributes/discard_max_size"]
==== discard_max_size

The maximum number of bytes that can be discarded by the logical unit's
underlying storage in a single operation.
A value of 0 means that the device does not support discard functionality.

NOTE: This is the software limit, and not the hardware limit, as noted in the
https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/block/queue-sysfs.txt[documentation] of
`queue-sysfs` for `discard_max_bytes`.

[id="types/logical_unit/attributes/discard_zeroes_data"]
==== discard_zeroes_data

True, if previously discarded blocks in the logical
unit's underlying storage are read back as zeros.
For more information please see the
https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/block/queue-sysfs.txt[documentation]
of `queue-sysfs` for `discard_zeroes_data`.

IMPORTANT: Since version 4.2.1 of the system, the support for this attribute has
been removed as the sysfs file, `discard_zeroes_data`, was deprecated in the kernel.
It is preserved for backwards compatibility, but the value will always be `false`.

[id="types/lun_status"]
=== LunStatus [small]#enum#

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`free`
|

|`unusable`
|

|`used`
|

|===

[id="types/mac"]
=== Mac [small]#struct#

Represents a MAC address of a virtual network interface.

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`address`
|<<types/string,String>>
|MAC address.

|===

[id="types/mac_pool"]
=== MacPool [small]#struct#

Represents a MAC address pool.

Example of an XML representation of a MAC address pool:

[source,xml]

<mac_pool href="/ovirt-engine/api/macpools/123" id="123"> <name>Default</name> <description>Default MAC pool</description> <allow_duplicates>false</allow_duplicates> <default_pool>true</default_pool> <ranges> <range> <from>00:1A:4A:16:01:51</from> <to>00:1A:4A:16:01:E6</to> </range> </ranges> </mac_pool>

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`allow_duplicates`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Defines whether duplicate MAC addresses are permitted in the pool.

|`comment`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Free text containing comments about this object.

|`default_pool`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Defines whether this is the default pool.

|`description`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable description in plain text.

|`id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A unique identifier.

|`name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable name in plain text.

|`ranges`
|<<types/range,Range[]>>
|Defines the range of MAC addresses for the pool.

|===

[id="types/mac_pool/attributes/allow_duplicates"]
==== allow_duplicates

Defines whether duplicate MAC addresses are permitted in the pool. If not specified, defaults to `false`.

[id="types/mac_pool/attributes/default_pool"]
==== default_pool

Defines whether this is the default pool. If not specified, defaults to `false`.

[id="types/mac_pool/attributes/ranges"]
==== ranges

Defines the range of MAC addresses for the pool. Multiple ranges can be defined.

[id="types/memory_over_commit"]
=== MemoryOverCommit [small]#struct#

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`percent`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|

|===

[id="types/memory_policy"]
=== MemoryPolicy [small]#struct#

Logical grouping of memory-related properties of virtual machine-like entities.

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`ballooning`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|

|`guaranteed`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|The amount of memory, in bytes, that is guaranteed to not be drained by the balloon mechanism.

|`max`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|Maximum virtual machine memory, in bytes.

|`over_commit`
|<<types/memory_over_commit,MemoryOverCommit>>
|

|`transparent_huge_pages`
|<<types/transparent_huge_pages,TransparentHugePages>>
|

|===

[id="types/memory_policy/attributes/guaranteed"]
==== guaranteed

The amount of memory, in bytes, that is guaranteed to not be drained by the balloon mechanism.

The {engine-name} internally rounds this value down to whole MiB (1MiB = 2^20^ bytes).

NOTE: It can be updated while the virtual machine is running since {product-name} 4.2 onwards, provided
<<types/vm/attributes/memory, memory>> is updated in the same request as well, and the virtual machine is in
state <<types/vm_status/values/up, up>>.

[id="types/memory_policy/attributes/max"]
==== max

Maximum virtual machine memory, in bytes.

The user provides the value in bytes, and the {engine-name} rounds the value down to the nearest lower MiB value.

For example, if the user enters a value of 1073741825 (1 GiB + 1 byte), then the {engine-name} will truncate
that value to the nearest lower MiB boundary: in this case 1073741824 (1 GiB).

[id="types/message_broker_type"]
=== MessageBrokerType [small]#enum#

Deprecated Message Broker type.

Ignored, because the deployment of OpenStack Neutron agent is dropped since {product-name} 4.4.0.

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`qpid`
|

|`rabbit_mq`
|

|===

[id="types/migration_bandwidth"]
=== MigrationBandwidth [small]#struct#

Defines the bandwidth used by migration.

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`assignment_method`
|<<types/migration_bandwidth_assignment_method,MigrationBandwidthAssignmentMethod>>
|The method used to assign the bandwidth.

|`custom_value`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|Custom bandwidth in Mbps.

|===

[id="types/migration_bandwidth/attributes/custom_value"]
==== custom_value

Custom bandwidth in Mbps. Will be applied only if the `assignmentMethod` attribute is `custom`.

[id="types/migration_bandwidth_assignment_method"]
=== MigrationBandwidthAssignmentMethod [small]#enum#

Defines how the migration bandwidth is assigned.

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`auto`
|Takes the bandwidth from the Quality of Service if the Quality of Service is defined.

|`custom`
|Custom defined bandwidth in Mbit/s.

|`hypervisor_default`
|Takes the value as configured on the hypervisor.

|===

[id="types/migration_bandwidth_assignment_method/values/auto"]
==== auto

Takes the bandwidth from the Quality of Service if the Quality of Service is defined.
If the Quality of Service is not defined the bandwidth is taken from the detected link speed being used.
If nothing is detected, bandwidth falls back to the hypervisor_default value.

|===
