[id="types/scsi_generic_i_o"]
=== ScsiGenericIO [small]#enum#

When a direct LUN disk is using SCSI passthrough the privileged I/O policy is determined by this enum.

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`disabled`
|Disable SCSI passthrough.

|`filtered`
|Disallow privileged SCSI I/O.

|`unfiltered`
|Allow privileged SCSI I/O.

|===

[id="types/se_linux"]
=== SeLinux [small]#struct#

Represents SELinux in the system.

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`mode`
|<<types/se_linux_mode,SeLinuxMode>>
|SELinux current mode.

|===

[id="types/se_linux_mode"]
=== SeLinuxMode [small]#enum#

Represents an SELinux enforcement mode.

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`disabled`
|SELinux is disabled in the kernel.

|`enforcing`
|SELinux is running and enforcing permissions.

|`permissive`
|SELinux is running and logging but not enforcing permissions.

|===

[id="types/serial_number"]
=== SerialNumber [small]#struct#

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`policy`
|<<types/serial_number_policy,SerialNumberPolicy>>
|

|`value`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|===

[id="types/serial_number_policy"]
=== SerialNumberPolicy [small]#enum#

Type representing the policy of a Serial Number.

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`custom`
|This policy allows the user to provide an arbitrary string as the Serial Number.

|`host`
|This policy is the legacy policy.

|`none`
|This policy is used to remove the Serial Number Policy, moving it to default: null.

|`vm`
|This policy will use the Virtual Machine ID as the Serial Number.

|===

[id="types/serial_number_policy/values/host"]
==== host

This policy is the legacy policy. It will use the Host ID as the Serial Number.

[id="types/session"]
=== Session [small]#struct#

Describes a user session to a virtual machine.

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`comment`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Free text containing comments about this object.

|`console_user`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Indicates if this is a console session.

|`description`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable description in plain text.

|`id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A unique identifier.

|`ip`
|<<types/ip,Ip>>
|The IP address the user is connected from.

|`name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable name in plain text.

|`protocol`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The protocol used by the session.

|===

[id="types/session/attributes/console_user"]
==== console_user

Indicates if this is a console session.

The value will be `true` for console users (SPICE or VNC), and `false` for others (such as RDP or SSH).

[id="types/session/attributes/ip"]
==== ip

The IP address the user is connected from.

Currently only available for console users.

[id="types/session/attributes/protocol"]
==== protocol

The protocol used by the session.

Currently not used. Intended for info about how the user is connected: through SPICE, VNC, SSH, or RDP.

.Links summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`user`
|<<types/user,User>>
|The user related to this session.

|`vm`
|<<types/vm,Vm>>
|A link to the virtual machine related to this session.

|===

[id="types/session/links/user"]
==== user

The user related to this session.

If the user is a console user, this is a link to the real {product-name} user. Otherwise, only the user name is provided.

[id="types/skip_if_connectivity_broken"]
=== SkipIfConnectivityBroken [small]#struct#

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`enabled`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|If enabled, we will not fence a host
in case more than a configurable percentage
of hosts in the cluster lost connectivity as well.

|`threshold`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|Threshold for connectivity testing.

|===

[id="types/skip_if_connectivity_broken/attributes/enabled"]
==== enabled

If enabled, we will not fence a host
in case more than a configurable percentage
of hosts in the cluster lost connectivity as well.
This comes to prevent fencing _storm_ in cases
where there is a global networking issue in the
cluster.

[id="types/skip_if_connectivity_broken/attributes/threshold"]
==== threshold

Threshold for connectivity testing.
If at least the threshold percentage of hosts in the cluster
lost connectivity then fencing will not take place.

[id="types/skip_if_sd_active"]
=== SkipIfSdActive [small]#struct#

This type represents the storage related
configuration in the fencing policy.

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`enabled`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|If enabled, we will skip fencing in case the host
maintains its lease in the storage.

|===

[id="types/skip_if_sd_active/attributes/enabled"]
==== enabled

If enabled, we will skip fencing in case the host
maintains its lease in the storage. It means that
if the host still has storage access then it won't
get fenced.

[id="types/snapshot"]
=== Snapshot [small]#struct#

Represents a snapshot object.

Example XML representation:

[source,xml]

<snapshot id="456" href="/ovirt-engine/api/vms/123/snapshots/456"> <actions> <link rel="restore" href="/ovirt-engine/api/vms/123/snapshots/456/restore"/> </actions> <vm id="123" href="/ovirt-engine/api/vms/123"/> <description>Virtual Machine 1 - Snapshot A</description> <type>active</type> <date>2010-08-16T14:24:29</date> <persist_memorystate>false</persist_memorystate> </snapshot>

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`bios`
|<<types/bios,Bios>>
|Reference to virtual machine's BIOS configuration.

|`comment`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Free text containing comments about this object.

|`console`
|<<types/console,Console>>
|Console configured for this virtual machine.

|`cpu`
|<<types/cpu,Cpu>>
|The configuration of the virtual machine CPU.

|`cpu_shares`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|

|`creation_time`
|<<types/date,Date>>
|The virtual machine creation date.

|`custom_compatibility_version`
|<<types/version,Version>>
|Virtual machine custom compatibility version.

|`custom_cpu_model`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`custom_emulated_machine`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`custom_properties`
|<<types/custom_property,CustomProperty[]>>
|Properties sent to VDSM to configure various hooks.

|`date`
|<<types/date,Date>>
|The date when this snapshot has been created.

|`delete_protected`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|If `true`, the virtual machine cannot be deleted.

|`description`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable description in plain text.

|`display`
|<<types/display,Display>>
|The virtual machine display configuration.

|`domain`
|<<types/domain,Domain>>
|Domain configured for this virtual machine.

|`fqdn`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Fully qualified domain name of the virtual machine.

|`guest_operating_system`
|<<types/guest_operating_system,GuestOperatingSystem>>
|What operating system is installed on the virtual machine.

|`guest_time_zone`
|<<types/time_zone,TimeZone>>
|What time zone is used by the virtual machine (as returned by guest agent).

|`has_illegal_images`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Indicates whether the virtual machine has snapshots with disks in `ILLEGAL` state.

|`high_availability`
|<<types/high_availability,HighAvailability>>
|The virtual machine high availability configuration.

|`id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A unique identifier.

|`initialization`
|<<types/initialization,Initialization>>
|Reference to the virtual machine's initialization configuration.

|`io`
|<<types/io,Io>>
|For performance tuning of IO threading.

|`large_icon`
|<<types/icon,Icon>>
|Virtual machine's large icon.

|`lease`
|<<types/storage_domain_lease,StorageDomainLease>>
|Reference to the storage domain this virtual machine/template lease reside on.

|`memory`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|The virtual machine's memory, in bytes.

|`memory_policy`
|<<types/memory_policy,MemoryPolicy>>
|Reference to virtual machine's memory management configuration.

|`migration`
|<<types/migration_options,MigrationOptions>>
|Reference to configuration of migration of running virtual machine to another host.

|`migration_downtime`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|Maximum time the virtual machine can be non responsive during its live migration to another host in ms.

|`multi_queues_enabled`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|If `true`, each virtual interface will get the optimal number of queues, depending on the available virtual Cpus.

|`name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable name in plain text.

|`next_run_configuration_exists`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Virtual machine configuration has been changed and requires restart of the virtual machine.

|`numa_tune_mode`
|<<types/numa_tune_mode,NumaTuneMode>>
|How the NUMA topology is applied.

|`origin`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The origin of this virtual machine.

|`os`
|<<types/operating_system,OperatingSystem>>
|Operating system type installed on the virtual machine.

|`payloads`
|<<types/payload,Payload[]>>
|Optional payloads of the virtual machine, used for ISOs to configure it.

|`persist_memorystate`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Indicates if the content of the memory of the virtual machine is included in the snapshot.

|`placement_policy`
|<<types/vm_placement_policy,VmPlacementPolicy>>
|The configuration of the virtual machine's placement policy.

|`rng_device`
|<<types/rng_device,RngDevice>>
|Random Number Generator device configuration for this virtual machine.

|`run_once`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|If `true`, the virtual machine has been started using the _run once_ command, meaning
it's configuration might differ from the stored one for the purpose of this single run.

|`serial_number`
|<<types/serial_number,SerialNumber>>
|Virtual machine's serial number in a cluster.

|`small_icon`
|<<types/icon,Icon>>
|Virtual machine's small icon.

|`snapshot_status`
|<<types/snapshot_status,SnapshotStatus>>
|Status of the snapshot.

|`snapshot_type`
|<<types/snapshot_type,SnapshotType>>
|Type of the snapshot.

|`soundcard_enabled`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|If `true`, the sound card is added to the virtual machine.

|`sso`
|<<types/sso,Sso>>
|Reference to the Single Sign On configuration this virtual machine is configured for.

|`start_paused`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|If `true`, the virtual machine will be initially in 'paused' state after start.

|`start_time`
|<<types/date,Date>>
|The date in which the virtual machine was started.

|`stateless`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|If `true`, the virtual machine is stateless - it's state (disks) are rolled-back after shutdown.

|`status`
|<<types/vm_status,VmStatus>>
|The current status of the virtual machine.

|`status_detail`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Human readable detail of current status.

|`stop_reason`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The reason the virtual machine was stopped.

|`stop_time`
|<<types/date,Date>>
|The date in which the virtual machine was stopped.

|`storage_error_resume_behaviour`
|<<types/vm_storage_error_resume_behaviour,VmStorageErrorResumeBehaviour>>
|Determines how the virtual machine will be resumed after storage error.

|`time_zone`
|<<types/time_zone,TimeZone>>
|The virtual machine's time zone set by oVirt.

|`tunnel_migration`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|If `true`, the network data transfer will be encrypted during virtual machine live migration.

|`type`
|<<types/vm_type,VmType>>
|Determines whether the virtual machine is optimized for desktop or server.

|`usb`
|<<types/usb,Usb>>
|Configuration of USB devices for this virtual machine (count, type).

|`use_latest_template_version`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|If `true`, the virtual machine is reconfigured to the latest version of it's template when it is started.

|`virtio_scsi`
|<<types/virtio_scsi,VirtioScsi>>
|Reference to VirtIO SCSI configuration.

|===

[id="types/snapshot/attributes/cpu"]
==== cpu

The configuration of the virtual machine CPU.

The socket configuration can be updated without rebooting the virtual machine. The cores and the threads require
a reboot.

For example, to change the number of sockets to 4 immediately, and the number of cores and threads to 2 after
reboot, send the following request:

[source]

PUT /ovirt-engine/api/vms/123

With a request body:

[source,xml]

<vm> <cpu> <topology> <sockets>4</sockets> <cores>2</cores> <threads>2</threads> </topology> </cpu> </vm>

[id="types/snapshot/attributes/custom_compatibility_version"]
==== custom_compatibility_version

Virtual machine custom compatibility version.

Enables a virtual machine to be customized to its own compatibility version.  If
`custom_compatibility_version` is set, it overrides the cluster's compatibility version
for this particular virtual machine.

The compatibility version of a virtual machine is limited by the data center the virtual
machine resides in, and is checked against capabilities of the host the virtual machine is
planned to run on.

[id="types/snapshot/attributes/high_availability"]
==== high_availability

The virtual machine high availability configuration.
If set, the virtual machine will be automatically restarted when it unexpectedly goes down.

[id="types/snapshot/attributes/initialization"]
==== initialization

Reference to the virtual machine's initialization configuration.

NOTE: Since {product-name} 4.1.8 this property can be cleared by sending an empty tag.

For example, to clear the `initialization` attribute send a request like this:

[source]

PUT /ovirt-engine/api/vms/123

With a request body like this:

[source,xml]

<vm> <initialization/> </vm>

The response to such a request, and requests with the header `All-Content: true` will still contain this attribute.

[id="types/snapshot/attributes/large_icon"]
==== large_icon

Virtual machine's large icon. Either set by user or refers to image set according to operating system.

[id="types/snapshot/attributes/lease"]
==== lease

Reference to the storage domain this virtual machine/template lease reside on.

A virtual machine running with a lease requires checking while running that the lease is not taken by another
host, preventing another instance of this virtual machine from running on another host.
This provides protection against split-brain in highly available virtual machines.
A template can also have a storage domain defined for a lease in order to have the virtual machines created
from this template to be preconfigured with this storage domain as the location of the leases.

[id="types/snapshot/attributes/memory"]
==== memory

The virtual machine's memory, in bytes.

For example, to update a virtual machine to contain 1 Gibibyte (GiB) of memory, send the following request:

[source]

PUT /ovirt-engine/api/vms/123

With the following request body:

[source,xml]

<vm> <memory>1073741824</memory> </vm>

Memory hot plug is supported from {product-name} 3.6 onwards. You can use the example above to increase
memory while the virtual machine is in state <<types/vm_status/values/up, up>>. The size increment must be
dividable by the value of the `HotPlugMemoryBlockSizeMb` configuration value (256 MiB by default). If the memory
size increment is not dividable by this value, the memory size change is only stored to next run configuration.
Each successful memory hot plug operation creates one or two new memory devices.

Memory hot unplug is supported since {product-name} 4.2 onwards. Memory hot unplug can only be performed
when the virtual machine is in state <<types/vm_status/values/up, up>>. Only previously hot plugged memory
devices can be removed by the hot unplug operation. The requested memory decrement is rounded down to match sizes
of a combination of previously hot plugged memory devices. The requested memory value is stored to next run
configuration without rounding.

NOTE: Memory in the example is converted to bytes using the following formula: +
1 GiB = 2^30^ bytes = 1073741824 bytes.

NOTE: {engine-name} internally rounds values down to whole MiBs (1MiB = 2^20^ bytes)

[id="types/snapshot/attributes/migration_downtime"]
==== migration_downtime

Maximum time the virtual machine can be non responsive during its live migration to another host in ms.

Set either explicitly for the virtual machine or by `engine-config -s DefaultMaximumMigrationDowntime=[value]`

[id="types/snapshot/attributes/next_run_configuration_exists"]
==== next_run_configuration_exists

Virtual machine configuration has been changed and requires restart of the virtual machine.
Changed configuration is applied at processing the virtual machine's _shut down_.

[id="types/snapshot/attributes/origin"]
==== origin

The origin of this virtual machine.

Possible values:

- `ovirt`
- `rhev`
- `vmware`
- `xen`
- `external`
- `hosted_engine`
- `managed_hosted_engine`
- `kvm`
- `physical_machine`
- `hyperv`

[id="types/snapshot/attributes/persist_memorystate"]
==== persist_memorystate

Indicates if the content of the memory of the virtual machine is included in the snapshot.

When a snapshot is created the default value is `true`.

[id="types/snapshot/attributes/placement_policy"]
==== placement_policy

The configuration of the virtual machine's placement policy.

This configuration can be updated to pin a virtual machine to one or more hosts.

NOTE: Virtual machines that are pinned to multiple hosts cannot be live migrated, but in the event of a host
failure, any virtual machine configured to be highly available is automatically restarted on one of the other
hosts to which the virtual machine is pinned.

For example, to pin a virtual machine to two hosts, send the following request:

[source]

PUT /api/vms/123

With a request body like this:

[source,xml]

<vm> <high_availability> <enabled>true</enabled> <priority>1</priority> </high_availability> <placement_policy> <hosts> <host> <name>Host1</name> </host> <host> <name>Host2</name> </host> </hosts> <affinity>pinned</affinity> </placement_policy> </vm>

[id="types/snapshot/attributes/small_icon"]
==== small_icon

Virtual machine's small icon. Either set by user or refers to image set according to operating system.

[id="types/snapshot/attributes/sso"]
==== sso

Reference to the Single Sign On configuration this virtual machine is configured for.
The user can be automatically signed in the virtual machine's operating system when console is opened.

[id="types/snapshot/attributes/stop_reason"]
==== stop_reason

The reason the virtual machine was stopped.
Optionally set by user when shutting down the virtual machine.

.Links summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`affinity_labels`
|<<types/affinity_label,AffinityLabel[]>>
|Optional.

|`applications`
|<<types/application,Application[]>>
|List of applications installed on the virtual machine.

|`cdroms`
|<<types/cdrom,Cdrom[]>>
|Reference to the ISO mounted to the CDROM.

|`cluster`
|<<types/cluster,Cluster>>
|Reference to cluster the virtual machine belongs to.

|`cpu_profile`
|<<types/cpu_profile,CpuProfile>>
|Reference to CPU profile used by this virtual machine.

|`disk_attachments`
|<<types/disk_attachment,DiskAttachment[]>>
|References the disks attached to the virtual machine.

|`disks`
|<<types/disk,Disk[]>>
|List of disks linked to the snapshot.

|`external_host_provider`
|<<types/external_host_provider,ExternalHostProvider>>
|

|`floppies`
|<<types/floppy,Floppy[]>>
|Reference to the ISO mounted to the floppy.

|`graphics_consoles`
|<<types/graphics_console,GraphicsConsole[]>>
|List of graphics consoles configured for this virtual machine.

|`host`
|<<types/host,Host>>
|Reference to the host the virtual machine is running on.

|`host_devices`
|<<types/host_device,HostDevice[]>>
|References devices associated to this virtual machine.

|`instance_type`
|<<types/instance_type,InstanceType>>
|The virtual machine configuration can be optionally predefined via one of the instance types.

|`katello_errata`
|<<types/katello_erratum,KatelloErratum[]>>
|Lists all the Katello errata assigned to the virtual machine.

|`nics`
|<<types/nic,Nic[]>>
|References the list of network interface devices on the virtual machine.

|`numa_nodes`
|<<types/numa_node,NumaNode[]>>
|Refers to the NUMA Nodes configuration used by this virtual machine.

|`original_template`
|<<types/template,Template>>
|References the original template used to create the virtual machine.

|`permissions`
|<<types/permission,Permission[]>>
|Permissions set for this virtual machine.

|`quota`
|<<types/quota,Quota>>
|Reference to quota configuration set for this virtual machine.

|`reported_devices`
|<<types/reported_device,ReportedDevice[]>>
|

|`sessions`
|<<types/session,Session[]>>
|List of user sessions opened for this virtual machine.

|`snapshots`
|<<types/snapshot,Snapshot[]>>
|Refers to all snapshots taken from the virtual machine.

|`statistics`
|<<types/statistic,Statistic[]>>
|Statistics data collected from this virtual machine.

|`storage_domain`
|<<types/storage_domain,StorageDomain>>
|Reference to storage domain the virtual machine belongs to.

|`tags`
|<<types/tag,Tag[]>>
|

|`template`
|<<types/template,Template>>
|Reference to the template the virtual machine is based on.

|`vm`
|<<types/vm,Vm>>
|The virtual machine this snapshot has been taken for.

|`vm_pool`
|<<types/vm_pool,VmPool>>
|Reference to the pool the virtual machine is optionally member of.

|`watchdogs`
|<<types/watchdog,Watchdog[]>>
|Refers to the Watchdog configuration.

|===

[id="types/snapshot/links/affinity_labels"]
==== affinity_labels

Optional. Used for labeling of sub-clusters.

[id="types/snapshot/links/katello_errata"]
==== katello_errata

Lists all the Katello errata assigned to the virtual machine.

[source]

GET /ovirt-engine/api/vms/123/katelloerrata

You will receive response in XML like this one:

[source,xml]

<katello_errata> <katello_erratum href="/ovirt-engine/api/katelloerrata/456" id="456"> <name>RHBA-2013:XYZ</name> <description>The description of the erratum</description> <title>some bug fix update</title> <type>bugfix</type> <issued>2013-11-20T02:00:00.000+02:00</issued> <solution>Few guidelines regarding the solution</solution> <summary>Updated packages that fix one bug are now available for XYZ</summary> <packages> <package> <name>libipa_hbac-1.9.2-82.11.el6_4.i686</name> </package> …​ </packages> </katello_erratum> …​ </katello_errata>

[id="types/snapshot/links/original_template"]
==== original_template

References the original template used to create the virtual machine.

If the virtual machine is cloned from a template or another virtual machine,
the `template` links to the Blank template, and the `original_template`
is used to track history.

Otherwise the `template` and `original_template` are the same.

[id="types/snapshot/links/statistics"]
==== statistics

Statistics data collected from this virtual machine.

Note that some statistics, notably `memory.buffered` and `memory.cached`
are available only when https://www.ovirt.org/documentation/vmm-guide/chap-Installing_Linux_Virtual_Machines.html#installing-guest-agents-and-drivers[oVirt guest agent]
is installed in the virtual machine.

[id="types/snapshot_status"]
=== SnapshotStatus [small]#enum#

Represents the current status of the snapshot.

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`in_preview`
|The snapshot is being previewed.

|`locked`
|The snapshot is locked.

|`ok`
|The snapshot is OK.

|===

[id="types/snapshot_status/values/locked"]
==== locked

The snapshot is locked.

The snapshot is locked when it is in process of being created, deleted, restored or previewed.

[id="types/snapshot_type"]
=== SnapshotType [small]#enum#

Represents the type of the snapshot.

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`active`
|Reference to the current configuration of the virtual machines.

|`preview`
|The `active` snapshot will become `preview` if some snapshot is being previewed.

|`regular`
|Snapshot created by user.

|`stateless`
|Snapshot created internally for stateless virtual machines.

|===

[id="types/snapshot_type/values/preview"]
==== preview

The `active` snapshot will become `preview` if some snapshot is being previewed.

In other words, this is the `active` snapshot before preview.

[id="types/snapshot_type/values/stateless"]
==== stateless

Snapshot created internally for stateless virtual machines.

This snapshot is created when the virtual machine is started and it is restored when the virtual machine is shut
down.

.Links summary

|Name |Type |Summary

|`blank_template`
|<<types/template,Template>>
|A reference to a blank template.

|`root_tag`
|<<types/tag,Tag>>
|A reference to the root of a hierarchy of tags.

|===

[id="types/statistic"]
=== Statistic [small]#struct#

A generic type used for all kinds of statistics.

Statistic contains the statistics values for various entities.
The following object contain statistics:

* Disk
* Host
* HostNic
* NumaNode
* Nic
* Vm
* GlusterBrick
* Step
* GlusterVolume

An example of a XML representation:

[source,xml]

<statistics> <statistic id="1234" href="/ovirt-engine/api/hosts/1234/nics/1234/statistics/1234"> <name>data.current.rx</name> <description>Receive data rate</description> <values type="DECIMAL"> <value> <datum>0</datum> </value> </values> <type>GAUGE</type> <unit>BYTES_PER_SECOND</unit> <host_nic id="1234" href="/ovirt-engine/api/hosts/1234/nics/1234"/> </statistic> …​ </statistics>

NOTE: This statistics sub-collection is read-only.

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`comment`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Free text containing comments about this object.

|`description`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable description in plain text.

|`id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A unique identifier.

|`kind`
|<<types/statistic_kind,StatisticKind>>
|The type of statistic measures.

|`name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable name in plain text.

|`type`
|<<types/value_type,ValueType>>
|The data type for the statistical values that follow.

|`unit`
|<<types/statistic_unit,StatisticUnit>>
|The unit or rate to measure of the statistical values.

|`values`
|<<types/value,Value[]>>
|A data set that contains `datum`.

|===

.Links summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`brick`
|<<types/gluster_brick,GlusterBrick>>
|

|`disk`
|<<types/disk,Disk>>
|A relationship to the containing `disk` resource.

|`gluster_volume`
|<<types/gluster_volume,GlusterVolume>>
|

|`host`
|<<types/host,Host>>
|

|`host_nic`
|<<types/host_nic,HostNic>>
|A reference to the host NIC.

|`host_numa_node`
|<<types/numa_node,NumaNode>>
|

|`nic`
|<<types/nic,Nic>>
|

|`step`
|<<types/step,Step>>
|

|`vm`
|<<types/vm,Vm>>
|

|===

[id="types/statistic_kind"]
=== StatisticKind [small]#enum#

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`counter`
|

|`gauge`
|

|===

[id="types/statistic_unit"]

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`bits_per_second`

|`bytes`

|`bytes_per_second`

|`count_per_second`
|

|`none`
|

|`percent`
|

|`seconds`

|===

[id="types/step"]
=== Step [small]#struct#

Represents a step, which is part of `job` execution.
Step is used to describe and track a specific execution unit which is part of a wider sequence.
Some steps support reporting their progress.

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`comment`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Free text containing comments about this object.

|`description`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable description in plain text.

|`end_time`
|<<types/date,Date>>
|The end time of the step.

|`external`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Indicates if the step is originated by an external system.

|`external_type`
|<<types/external_system_type,ExternalSystemType>>
|The external system which is referenced by the step.

|`id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A unique identifier.

|`name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable name in plain text.

|`number`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|The order of the step in current hierarchy level.

|`progress`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|The step progress (if reported) in percentages.

|`start_time`
|<<types/date,Date>>
|The start time of the step.

|`status`
|<<types/step_status,StepStatus>>
|The status of the step.

|`type`
|<<types/step_enum,StepEnum>>
|The type of the step.

|===

[id="types/step/attributes/external"]
==== external

Indicates if the step is originated by an external system.
External steps are managed externally, by the creator of the step.

.Links summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`execution_host`
|<<types/host,Host>>
|The host used for the step execution (optional).

|`job`
|<<types/job,Job>>
|References the `job` which is the top of the current step hierarchy.

|`parent_step`
|<<types/step,Step>>
|References the parent step of the current step in the hierarchy.

|`statistics`
|<<types/statistic,Statistic[]>>
|

|===

[id="types/step_enum"]
=== StepEnum [small]#enum#

Type representing a step type.

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`executing`
|The executing step type.

|`finalizing`
|The finalizing step type.

|`rebalancing_volume`
|The `rebalancing volume` step type.

|`removing_bricks`
|The `removing bricks` step type.

|`unknown`
|The unknown step type.

|`validating`
|The validation step type.

|===

[id="types/step_enum/values/executing"]
==== executing

The executing step type.
Used to track the main execution block of the job.
Usually it will be a parent step of several sub-steps which describe portions of the execution step.

[id="types/step_enum/values/finalizing"]
==== finalizing

The finalizing step type.
Describes the post-execution steps requires to complete the `job`.

[id="types/step_enum/values/rebalancing_volume"]
==== rebalancing_volume

The `rebalancing volume` step type.
Describes a step type which is part of `Gluster` flow.

[id="types/step_enum/values/removing_bricks"]
==== removing_bricks

The `removing bricks` step type.
Describes a step type which is part of `Gluster` flow.

[id="types/step_enum/values/unknown"]
==== unknown

The unknown step type.
Describes a step type which its origin is unknown.

[id="types/step_enum/values/validating"]
==== validating

The validation step type.
Used to verify the correctness of parameters and the validity of the parameters prior to the execution.

[id="types/step_status"]
=== StepStatus [small]#enum#

Represents the status of the step.

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`aborted`
|The aborted step status.

|`failed`
|The failed step status.

|`finished`
|The finished step status.

|`started`
|The started step status.

|`unknown`
|The unknown step status.

|===

[id="types/step_status/values/aborted"]
==== aborted

The aborted step status.
This status is applicable for an external step that was forcibly aborted.

[id="types/step_status/values/finished"]
==== finished

The finished step status.
This status describes a completed step execution.

[id="types/step_status/values/started"]
==== started

The started step status.
This status represents a step which is currently being executed.

[id="types/step_status/values/unknown"]
==== unknown

The unknown step status.
This status represents steps which their resolution is not known, i.e. steps that were executed before
the system was unexpectedly restarted.

[id="types/storage_connection"]
=== StorageConnection [small]#struct#

Represents a storage server connection.

Example XML representation:

[source,xml]

<storage_connection id="123"> <address>mynfs.example.com</address> <type>nfs</type> <path>/exports/mydata</path> </storage_connection>

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`address`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A storage server connection's address.

|`comment`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Free text containing comments about this object.

|`description`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable description in plain text.

|`id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A unique identifier.

|`mount_options`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The mount options of an NFS storage server connection.

|`name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable name in plain text.

|`nfs_retrans`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|The NFS retrans value of an NFS storage server connection.

|`nfs_timeo`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|The NFS timeo value of an NFS storage server connection.

|`nfs_version`
|<<types/nfs_version,NfsVersion>>
|The NFS version of an NFS storage server connection.

|`password`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The password of an iSCSI storage server connection.

|`path`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The path of an NFS storage server connection.

|`port`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|The port of an iSCSI storage server connection.

|`portal`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The portal of an iSCSI storage server connection.

|`target`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The target of an iSCSI storage server connection.

|`type`
|<<types/storage_type,StorageType>>
|A storage server connection's type.

|`username`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The user name of an iSCSI storage server connection.

|`vfs_type`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The VFS type of an NFS storage server connection.

|===

.Links summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`gluster_volume`
|<<types/gluster_volume,GlusterVolume>>
|Link to the gluster volume, used by that storage domain.

|`host`
|<<types/host,Host>>
|

|===

[id="types/storage_connection_extension"]
=== StorageConnectionExtension [small]#struct#

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`comment`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Free text containing comments about this object.

|`description`

|`id`
|<<types/string,String>>

|`name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable name in plain text.

|`password`

|

|`target`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`username`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|===

.Links summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`host`
|<<types/host,Host>>
|

|===

[id="types/storage_domain"]
=== StorageDomain [small]#struct#

Storage domain.

An XML representation of a NFS storage domain with identifier `123`:

[source,xml]

<storage_domain href="/ovirt-engine/api/storagedomains/123" id="123"> <name>mydata</name> <description>My data</description> <available>38654705664</available> <committed>1073741824</committed> <critical_space_action_blocker>5</critical_space_action_blocker> <external_status>ok</external_status> <master>true</master> <storage> <address>mynfs.example.com</address> <nfs_version>v3</nfs_version> <path>/exports/mydata</path> <type>nfs</type> </storage> <storage_format>v3</storage_format> <type>data</type> <used>13958643712</used> <warning_low_space_indicator>10</warning_low_space_indicator> <wipe_after_delete>false</wipe_after_delete> <data_centers> <data_center href="/ovirt-engine/api/datacenters/456" id="456"/> </data_centers> </storage_domain>

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`available`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|

|`backup`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|This attribute indicates whether a data storage domain is used as backup
domain or not.

|`block_size`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|Specifies block size in bytes for a storage domain.

|`comment`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Free text containing comments about this object.

|`committed`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|

|`critical_space_action_blocker`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|

|`description`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable description in plain text.

|`discard_after_delete`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Indicates whether <<types/disk, disk>>s' blocks on block <<types/storage_domain, storage domain>>s will be
discarded right before they are deleted.

|`external_status`
|<<types/external_status,ExternalStatus>>
|

|`id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A unique identifier.

|`import`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|

|`master`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|

|`name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable name in plain text.

|`status`
|<<types/storage_domain_status,StorageDomainStatus>>
|

|`storage`
|<<types/host_storage,HostStorage>>
|

|`storage_format`
|<<types/storage_format,StorageFormat>>
|

|`supports_discard`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Indicates whether a block storage domain supports discard operations.

|`supports_discard_zeroes_data`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Indicates whether a block storage domain supports the property that
discard zeroes the data.

|`type`
|<<types/storage_domain_type,StorageDomainType>>
|

|`used`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|

|`warning_low_space_indicator`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|

|`wipe_after_delete`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Serves as the default value of `wipe_after_delete` for <<types/disk, disk>>s on this
<<types/storage_domain, storage domain>>.

|===

[id="types/storage_domain/attributes/backup"]
==== backup

This attribute indicates whether a data storage domain is used as backup
domain or not. If the domain is set to backup then it will be used
to store virtual machines and templates for disaster recovery purposes in the
same way we use export storage domain. This attribute is only available
with data storage domain and not with ISO domain or export storage domain.
User can use this functionality while creating a data storage domain
or importing a data storage domain.

[id="types/storage_domain/attributes/block_size"]
==== block_size

Specifies block size in bytes for a storage domain.
Can be omitted and in that case will be defaulted to 512 bytes.
Not all storage domains support all possible sizes.

[id="types/storage_domain/attributes/discard_after_delete"]
==== discard_after_delete

Indicates whether <<types/disk, disk>>s' blocks on block <<types/storage_domain, storage domain>>s will be
discarded right before they are deleted.

If true, and a disk on this storage domain has its `wipe_after_delete` value enabled, then when the disk is
deleted:

. It is first wiped.
. Then its blocks are discarded.
. Finally it is deleted.

Note that:

* Discard after delete will always be `false` for non block storage types.

* Discard after delete can be set to `true` only if the storage domain
<<types/storage_domain/attributes/supports_discard, supports discard>>.

[id="types/storage_domain/attributes/supports_discard"]
==== supports_discard

Indicates whether a block storage domain supports discard operations.
A <<types/storage_domain,storage domain>> only supports discard
if all of the <<types/logical_unit, logical unit>>s that it is built
from support discard; that is, if each logical unit's `discard_max_size` value
is greater than 0.
This is one of the conditions necessary for a virtual disk in this
storage domain to have its `pass_discard` attribute enabled.

[id="types/storage_domain/attributes/supports_discard_zeroes_data"]
==== supports_discard_zeroes_data

Indicates whether a block storage domain supports the property that
discard zeroes the data.
A <<types/storage_domain,storage domain>> only supports the property that
discard zeroes the data if all of the
<<types/logical_unit, logical unit>>s that it is built from support it;
that is, if each logical unit's `discard_zeroes_data` value is true.

IMPORTANT: Since version 4.2.1 of the system, the support for this attribute has
been removed as the sysfs file, `discard_zeroes_data`, was deprecated in the kernel.
It is preserved for backwards compatibility, but the value will always be `false`.

[id="types/storage_domain/attributes/wipe_after_delete"]
==== wipe_after_delete

Serves as the default value of `wipe_after_delete` for <<types/disk, disk>>s on this
<<types/storage_domain, storage domain>>.

That is, newly created disks will get their `wipe_after_delete` value from their storage domains by default.
Note that the configuration value `SANWipeAfterDelete` serves as the default value of block storage domains'
`wipe_after_delete` value.

.Links summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`data_center`
|<<types/data_center,DataCenter>>
|A link to the data center that the storage domain is attached to.

|`data_centers`
|<<types/data_center,DataCenter[]>>
|A set of links to the data centers that the storage domain is attached to.

|`disk_profiles`
|<<types/disk_profile,DiskProfile[]>>
|

|`disk_snapshots`
|<<types/disk_snapshot,DiskSnapshot[]>>
|

|`disks`
|<<types/disk,Disk[]>>
|

|`files`
|<<types/file,File[]>>
|

|`host`
|<<types/host,Host>>
|Host is only relevant at creation time.

|`images`
|<<types/image,Image[]>>
|

|`permissions`
|<<types/permission,Permission[]>>
|

|`storage_connections`
|<<types/storage_connection,StorageConnection[]>>
|

|`templates`
|<<types/template,Template[]>>
|

|`vms`
|<<types/vm,Vm[]>>
|

|===

[id="types/storage_domain/links/data_center"]
==== data_center

A link to the data center that the storage domain is attached to. This is preserved for backwards
compatibility only, as the storage domain may be attached to multiple data centers (if it is an ISO domain). Use
the `dataCenters` element instead.

[id="types/storage_domain_lease"]
=== StorageDomainLease [small]#struct#

Represents a lease residing on a storage domain.

A lease is a http://www.ovirt.org/develop/developer-guide/vdsm/sanlock[Sanlock] resource residing on a special
volume on the storage domain, this Sanlock resource is used to provide storage base locking.

.Links summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`storage_domain`
|<<types/storage_domain,StorageDomain>>
|Reference to the storage domain on which the lock resides on.

|===

[id="types/storage_domain_status"]
=== StorageDomainStatus [small]#enum#

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`activating`
|

|`active`
|

|`detaching`
|

|`inactive`
|

|`locked`
|

|`maintenance`
|

|`mixed`
|

|`preparing_for_maintenance`
|

|`unattached`
|

|`unknown`
|

|===

[id="types/storage_domain_type"]
=== StorageDomainType [small]#enum#

Indicates the kind of data managed by a <<types/storage_domain, storage domain>>.

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`data`
|Data domains are used to store the disks and snapshots of the virtual machines and templates in the system.

|`export`
|Export domains are temporary storage repositories used to copy and move virtual machines and templates between
data centers and {product-name} environments.

|`image`
|Image domain store images that can be imported into from an external system.

|`iso`
|ISO domains store ISO files (or logical CDs) used to install and boot operating systems and applications for the
virtual machines.

|`managed_block_storage`
|Managed block storage domains are created on block storage devices.

|`volume`
|Volume domains store logical volumes that can be used as disks for virtual machines.

|===

[id="types/storage_domain_type/values/data"]
==== data

Data domains are used to store the disks and snapshots of the virtual machines and templates in the system. In
addition, snapshots of the disks are also stored in data domains. Data domains cannot be shared across data
centers.

[id="types/storage_domain_type/values/export"]
==== export

Export domains are temporary storage repositories used to copy and move virtual machines and templates between
data centers and {product-name} environments. Export domains can also be used to backup virtual machines. An
export domain can be moved between data centers but it can only be active in one data center at a time.

[id="types/storage_domain_type/values/image"]
==== image

Image domain store images that can be imported into from an external system. For example, images from an
OpenStack Glance image repository.

[id="types/storage_domain_type/values/iso"]
==== iso

ISO domains store ISO files (or logical CDs) used to install and boot operating systems and applications for the
virtual machines. ISO domains remove the data center's need for physical media. An ISO domain can be shared
across different data centers.

[id="types/storage_domain_type/values/managed_block_storage"]
==== managed_block_storage

Managed block storage domains are created on block storage devices. These domains are accessed and managed by cinder.

[id="types/storage_domain_type/values/volume"]
==== volume

Volume domains store logical volumes that can be used as disks for virtual machines. For example, volumes
from an OpenStack Cincer block storage service.

[id="types/storage_format"]
=== StorageFormat [small]#enum#

Type which represents a format of <<types/storage_domain, storage domain>>.

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`v1`
|Version 1 of the storage domain format is applicable to NFS, iSCSI and FC storage domains.

|`v2`
|Version 2 of the storage domain format is applicable to iSCSI and FC storage domains.

|`v3`
|Version 3 of the storage domain format is applicable to NFS, POSIX, iSCSI and FC storage domains.

|`v4`
|Version 4 of the storage domain format.

|`v5`
|Version 5 of the storage domain format is applicable to NFS, POSIX, and Gluster storage domains.

|===

[id="types/storage_format/values/v1"]
==== v1

Version 1 of the storage domain format is applicable to NFS, iSCSI and FC storage domains.

Each storage domain contains metadata describing its own structure, and all of the names of physical volumes that
are used to back virtual machine disk images. Master domains additionally contain metadata for all the domains
and physical volume names in the storage pool. The total size of this metadata is limited to 2 KiB, limiting the
number of storage domains that can be in a pool. Template and virtual machine base images are read only.

[id="types/storage_format/values/v2"]
==== v2

Version 2 of the storage domain format is applicable to iSCSI and FC storage domains.

All storage domain and pool metadata is stored as logical volume tags rather than written to a logical volume.
Metadata about virtual machine disk volumes is still stored in a logical volume on the domains. Physical volume
names are no longer included in the metadata. Template and virtual machine base images are read only.

[id="types/storage_format/values/v3"]
==== v3

Version 3 of the storage domain format is applicable to NFS, POSIX, iSCSI and FC storage domains.

All storage domain and pool metadata is stored as logical volume tags rather than written to a logical volume.
Metadata about virtual machine disk volumes is still stored in a logical volume on the domains. Virtual machine
and template base images are no longer read only. This change enables live snapshots, live storage migration,
and clone from snapshot. Support for Unicode metadata is added, for non-English volume names.

[id="types/storage_format/values/v5"]
==== v5

Version 5 of the storage domain format is applicable to NFS, POSIX, and Gluster storage domains.

Added support for 4096 bytes block sizes and variable sanlock alignments.

[id="types/storage_type"]
=== StorageType [small]#enum#

Type representing a storage domain type.

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`cinder`
|Cinder storage domain.

|`fcp`
|Fibre-Channel storage domain.

|`glance`
|Glance storage domain.

|`glusterfs`
|Gluster-FS storage domain.

|`iscsi`
|iSCSI storage domain.

|`localfs`
|Storage domain on Local storage.

|`managed_block_storage`
|Managed block storage domain.

|`nfs`
|NFS storage domain.

|`posixfs`
|POSIX-FS storage domain.

|===

[id="types/storage_type/values/cinder"]
==== cinder

Cinder storage domain.
For more details on Cinder please go to https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Cinder[Cinder].

[id="types/storage_type/values/glance"]
==== glance

Glance storage domain.
For more details on Glance please go to https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Glance[Glance].

[id="types/storage_type/values/glusterfs"]
==== glusterfs

Gluster-FS storage domain.
For more details on Gluster please go to https://www.gluster.org/[Gluster].

[id="types/storage_type/values/managed_block_storage"]
==== managed_block_storage

Managed block storage domain.
A storage domain managed using cinderlib.
For supported storage drivers, see https://docs.openstack.org/cinder/rocky/drivers.html[Available Drivers].

[id="types/switch_type"]

|`legacy`
|The native switch type.

|`ovs`
|The Open vSwitch type.

|===

[id="types/template"]
=== Template [small]#struct#

The type that represents a virtual machine template.
Templates allow for a rapid instantiation of virtual machines with common configuration and disk states.

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`bios`
|<<types/bios,Bios>>
|Reference to virtual machine's BIOS configuration.

|`comment`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Free text containing comments about this object.

|`console`
|<<types/console,Console>>
|Console configured for this virtual machine.

|`cpu`
|<<types/cpu,Cpu>>
|The configuration of the virtual machine CPU.

|`cpu_shares`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|

|`creation_time`
|<<types/date,Date>>
|The virtual machine creation date.

|`custom_compatibility_version`
|<<types/version,Version>>
|Virtual machine custom compatibility version.

|`custom_cpu_model`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`custom_emulated_machine`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`custom_properties`
|<<types/custom_property,CustomProperty[]>>
|Properties sent to VDSM to configure various hooks.

|`delete_protected`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|If `true`, the virtual machine cannot be deleted.

|`description`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable description in plain text.

|`display`
|<<types/display,Display>>
|The virtual machine display configuration.

|`domain`
|<<types/domain,Domain>>
|Domain configured for this virtual machine.

|`high_availability`
|<<types/high_availability,HighAvailability>>
|The virtual machine high availability configuration.

|`id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A unique identifier.

|`initialization`
|<<types/initialization,Initialization>>
|Reference to the virtual machine's initialization configuration.

|`io`
|<<types/io,Io>>
|For performance tuning of IO threading.

|`large_icon`
|<<types/icon,Icon>>
|Virtual machine's large icon.

|`lease`
|<<types/storage_domain_lease,StorageDomainLease>>
|Reference to the storage domain this virtual machine/template lease reside on.

|`memory`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|The virtual machine's memory, in bytes.

|`memory_policy`
|<<types/memory_policy,MemoryPolicy>>
|Reference to virtual machine's memory management configuration.

|`migration`
|<<types/migration_options,MigrationOptions>>
|Reference to configuration of migration of running virtual machine to another host.

|`migration_downtime`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|Maximum time the virtual machine can be non responsive during its live migration to another host in ms.

|`multi_queues_enabled`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|If `true`, each virtual interface will get the optimal number of queues, depending on the available virtual Cpus.

|`name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable name in plain text.

|`origin`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The origin of this virtual machine.

|`os`
|<<types/operating_system,OperatingSystem>>
|Operating system type installed on the virtual machine.

|`placement_policy`
|<<types/vm_placement_policy,VmPlacementPolicy>>
|The configuration of the virtual machine's placement policy.

|`rng_device`
|<<types/rng_device,RngDevice>>
|Random Number Generator device configuration for this virtual machine.

|`serial_number`
|<<types/serial_number,SerialNumber>>
|Virtual machine's serial number in a cluster.

|`small_icon`
|<<types/icon,Icon>>
|Virtual machine's small icon.

|`soundcard_enabled`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|If `true`, the sound card is added to the virtual machine.

|`sso`
|<<types/sso,Sso>>
|Reference to the Single Sign On configuration this virtual machine is configured for.

|`start_paused`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|If `true`, the virtual machine will be initially in 'paused' state after start.

|`stateless`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|If `true`, the virtual machine is stateless - it's state (disks) are rolled-back after shutdown.

|`status`
|<<types/template_status,TemplateStatus>>
|The status of the template.

|`storage_error_resume_behaviour`
|<<types/vm_storage_error_resume_behaviour,VmStorageErrorResumeBehaviour>>
|Determines how the virtual machine will be resumed after storage error.

|`time_zone`
|<<types/time_zone,TimeZone>>
|The virtual machine's time zone set by oVirt.

|`tunnel_migration`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|If `true`, the network data transfer will be encrypted during virtual machine live migration.

|`type`
|<<types/vm_type,VmType>>
|Determines whether the virtual machine is optimized for desktop or server.

|`usb`
|<<types/usb,Usb>>
|Configuration of USB devices for this virtual machine (count, type).

|`version`
|<<types/template_version,TemplateVersion>>
|Indicates whether this is the base version or a sub-version of another template.

|`virtio_scsi`
|<<types/virtio_scsi,VirtioScsi>>
|Reference to VirtIO SCSI configuration.

|`vm`
|<<types/vm,Vm>>
|The virtual machine configuration associated with this template.

|===

[id="types/template/attributes/cpu"]
==== cpu

The configuration of the virtual machine CPU.

The socket configuration can be updated without rebooting the virtual machine. The cores and the threads require
a reboot.

For example, to change the number of sockets to 4 immediately, and the number of cores and threads to 2 after
reboot, send the following request:

[source]

PUT /ovirt-engine/api/vms/123

With a request body:

[source,xml]

<vm> <cpu> <topology> <sockets>4</sockets> <cores>2</cores> <threads>2</threads> </topology> </cpu> </vm>

[id="types/template/attributes/custom_compatibility_version"]
==== custom_compatibility_version

Virtual machine custom compatibility version.

Enables a virtual machine to be customized to its own compatibility version.  If
`custom_compatibility_version` is set, it overrides the cluster's compatibility version
for this particular virtual machine.

The compatibility version of a virtual machine is limited by the data center the virtual
machine resides in, and is checked against capabilities of the host the virtual machine is
planned to run on.

[id="types/template/attributes/high_availability"]
==== high_availability

The virtual machine high availability configuration.
If set, the virtual machine will be automatically restarted when it unexpectedly goes down.

[id="types/template/attributes/initialization"]
==== initialization

Reference to the virtual machine's initialization configuration.

NOTE: Since {product-name} 4.1.8 this property can be cleared by sending an empty tag.

For example, to clear the `initialization` attribute send a request like this:

[source]

PUT /ovirt-engine/api/vms/123

With a request body like this:

[source,xml]

<vm> <initialization/> </vm>

The response to such a request, and requests with the header `All-Content: true` will still contain this attribute.

[id="types/template/attributes/large_icon"]
==== large_icon

Virtual machine's large icon. Either set by user or refers to image set according to operating system.

[id="types/template/attributes/lease"]
==== lease

Reference to the storage domain this virtual machine/template lease reside on.

A virtual machine running with a lease requires checking while running that the lease is not taken by another
host, preventing another instance of this virtual machine from running on another host.
This provides protection against split-brain in highly available virtual machines.
A template can also have a storage domain defined for a lease in order to have the virtual machines created
from this template to be preconfigured with this storage domain as the location of the leases.

[id="types/template/attributes/memory"]
==== memory

The virtual machine's memory, in bytes.

For example, to update a virtual machine to contain 1 Gibibyte (GiB) of memory, send the following request:

[source]

PUT /ovirt-engine/api/vms/123

With the following request body:

[source,xml]

<vm> <memory>1073741824</memory> </vm>

Memory hot plug is supported from {product-name} 3.6 onwards. You can use the example above to increase
memory while the virtual machine is in state <<types/vm_status/values/up, up>>. The size increment must be
dividable by the value of the `HotPlugMemoryBlockSizeMb` configuration value (256 MiB by default). If the memory
size increment is not dividable by this value, the memory size change is only stored to next run configuration.
Each successful memory hot plug operation creates one or two new memory devices.

Memory hot unplug is supported since {product-name} 4.2 onwards. Memory hot unplug can only be performed
when the virtual machine is in state <<types/vm_status/values/up, up>>. Only previously hot plugged memory
devices can be removed by the hot unplug operation. The requested memory decrement is rounded down to match sizes
of a combination of previously hot plugged memory devices. The requested memory value is stored to next run
configuration without rounding.

NOTE: Memory in the example is converted to bytes using the following formula: +
1 GiB = 2^30^ bytes = 1073741824 bytes.

NOTE: {engine-name} internally rounds values down to whole MiBs (1MiB = 2^20^ bytes)

[id="types/template/attributes/migration_downtime"]
==== migration_downtime

Maximum time the virtual machine can be non responsive during its live migration to another host in ms.

Set either explicitly for the virtual machine or by `engine-config -s DefaultMaximumMigrationDowntime=[value]`

[id="types/template/attributes/origin"]
==== origin

The origin of this virtual machine.

Possible values:

- `ovirt`
- `rhev`
- `vmware`
- `xen`
- `external`
- `hosted_engine`
- `managed_hosted_engine`
- `kvm`
- `physical_machine`
- `hyperv`

[id="types/template/attributes/placement_policy"]
==== placement_policy

The configuration of the virtual machine's placement policy.

This configuration can be updated to pin a virtual machine to one or more hosts.

NOTE: Virtual machines that are pinned to multiple hosts cannot be live migrated, but in the event of a host
failure, any virtual machine configured to be highly available is automatically restarted on one of the other
hosts to which the virtual machine is pinned.

For example, to pin a virtual machine to two hosts, send the following request:

[source]

PUT /api/vms/123

With a request body like this:

[source,xml]

<vm> <high_availability> <enabled>true</enabled> <priority>1</priority> </high_availability> <placement_policy> <hosts> <host> <name>Host1</name> </host> <host> <name>Host2</name> </host> </hosts> <affinity>pinned</affinity> </placement_policy> </vm>

[id="types/template/attributes/small_icon"]
==== small_icon

Virtual machine's small icon. Either set by user or refers to image set according to operating system.

[id="types/template/attributes/sso"]
==== sso

Reference to the Single Sign On configuration this virtual machine is configured for.
The user can be automatically signed in the virtual machine's operating system when console is opened.

.Links summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`cdroms`
|<<types/cdrom,Cdrom[]>>
|Reference to the CD-ROM devices attached to the template.

|`cluster`
|<<types/cluster,Cluster>>
|Reference to cluster the virtual machine belongs to.

|`cpu_profile`
|<<types/cpu_profile,CpuProfile>>
|Reference to CPU profile used by this virtual machine.

|`disk_attachments`
|<<types/disk_attachment,DiskAttachment[]>>
|Reference to the disks attached to the template.

|`graphics_consoles`
|<<types/graphics_console,GraphicsConsole[]>>
|Reference to the graphic consoles attached to the template.

|`nics`
|<<types/nic,Nic[]>>
|Reference to the network interfaces attached to the template.

|`permissions`
|<<types/permission,Permission[]>>
|Reference to the user permissions attached to the template.

|`quota`
|<<types/quota,Quota>>
|Reference to quota configuration set for this virtual machine.

|`storage_domain`
|<<types/storage_domain,StorageDomain>>
|Reference to storage domain the virtual machine belongs to.

|`tags`
|<<types/tag,Tag[]>>
|Reference to the tags attached to the template.

|`watchdogs`
|<<types/watchdog,Watchdog[]>>
|Reference to the watchdog devices attached to the template.

|===

[id="types/template_status"]
=== TemplateStatus [small]#enum#

Type representing a status of a virtual machine template.

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`illegal`
|This status indicates that at least one of the disks of the template is illegal.

|`locked`
|This status indicates that some operation that prevents other operations with the template is being executed.

|`ok`
|This status indicates that the template is valid and ready for use.

|===

[id="types/template_version"]
=== TemplateVersion [small]#struct#

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]

|Name |Type |Summary

|`version_name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The name of this version.

|`version_number`

|The index of this version in the versions hierarchy of the template.

|===

[id="types/template_version/attributes/version_number"]
==== version_number

The index of this version in the versions hierarchy of the template.
The index 1 represents the original version of a template that is also called base version.

.Links summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`base_template`
|<<types/template,Template>>
|References the template that this version is associated with.

|===

[id="types/transparent_huge_pages"]

[id="types/unmanaged_network"]
=== UnmanagedNetwork [small]#struct#

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`comment`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Free text containing comments about this object.

|`description`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable description in plain text.

|`id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A unique identifier.

|`name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable name in plain text.

|===

.Links summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`host`
|<<types/host,Host>>
|

|`host_nic`
|<<types/host_nic,HostNic>>
|

|===

[id="types/usb"]
=== Usb [small]#struct#

Configuration of the USB device of a virtual machine.

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`enabled`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Determines whether the USB device should be included or not.

|`type`
|<<types/usb_type,UsbType>>
|USB type, currently only `native` is supported.

|===

[id="types/usb_type"]
=== UsbType [small]#enum#

Type of USB device redirection.

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`legacy`
|Legacy USB redirection.

|`native`
|Native USB redirection.

|===

[id="types/usb_type/values/legacy"]
==== legacy

Legacy USB redirection.

This USB type has been deprecated since version 3.6 of the engine, and has been completely removed in version
4.1. It is preserved only to avoid syntax errors in existing scripts. If it is used it will be automatically
replaced by `native`.

[id="types/usb_type/values/native"]
==== native

Native USB redirection.

Native USB redirection allows KVM/SPICE USB redirection for Linux and Windows virtual machines. Virtual (guest)
machines require no guest-installed agents or drivers for native USB. On Linux clients, all packages required
for USB redirection are provided by the `virt-viewer` package. On Windows clients, you must also install the
`usbdk` package.

[id="types/user"]
=== User [small]#struct#

Represents a user in the system.

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`comment`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Free text containing comments about this object.

|`department`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`description`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable description in plain text.

|`domain_entry_id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`email`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A unique identifier.

|`last_name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`logged_in`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|

|`name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable name in plain text.

|`namespace`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Namespace where the user resides.

|`password`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`principal`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Similar to `user_name`.

|`user_name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The user's username.

|===

[id="types/user/attributes/namespace"]
==== namespace

Namespace where the user resides. When using the authorization provider that stores users in the LDAP server,
this attribute equals the naming context of the LDAP server.
See https://github.com/oVirt/ovirt-engine-extension-aaa-ldap for more information.
When using the built-in authorization provider that stores users in the database this attribute is ignored.
See https://github.com/oVirt/ovirt-engine-extension-aaa-jdbc for more information.

[id="types/user/attributes/principal"]
==== principal

Similar to `user_name`. The format depends on the LDAP provider. With most LDAP providers it is the
value of the `uid` LDAP attribute. In the case of Active Directory it is the User Principal Name (UPN).

[id="types/user/attributes/user_name"]
==== user_name

The user's username. The format depends on authorization provider type. In most LDAP providers it is the
value of the `uid` LDAP attribute. In Active Directory it is the User Principal Name (UPN). `UPN` or
`uid` must be followed by the authorization provider name. For example, in the case of LDAP's `uid` attribute it is:
`myuser@myextension-authz`. In the case of Active Directory using `UPN` it is:
`myuser@mysubdomain.mydomain.com@myextension-authz`. This attribute is a required parameter when adding a new user.

.Links summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`domain`
|<<types/domain,Domain>>
|

|`groups`
|<<types/group,Group[]>>
|

|`permissions`
|<<types/permission,Permission[]>>
|

|`roles`
|<<types/role,Role[]>>
|A link to the roles sub-collection for user resources.

|`ssh_public_keys`
|<<types/ssh_public_key,SshPublicKey[]>>
|

|`tags`
|<<types/tag,Tag[]>>
|A link to the tags sub-collection for user resources.

|===

[id="types/vgpu_placement"]
=== VgpuPlacement [small]#enum#

The vGPU placement strategy.

It can either put vGPUs on the first available physical
cards, or spread them over multiple physical cards.

.Values summary
[cols="20,80"]
|===
|Name |Summary

|`consolidated`
|Use consolidated placement.

|`separated`
|Use separated placement.

|===

[id="types/vgpu_placement/values/consolidated"]
==== consolidated

Use consolidated placement. Each vGPU is placed on the first physical card with available space.

This is the default placement, utilizing all available space on the physical cards.

[id="types/vgpu_placement/values/separated"]
==== separated

Use separated placement. Each vGPU is placed on a separate physical card, if possible.

This can be useful for improving vGPU performance.

[id="types/virtio_scsi"]
=== VirtioScsi [small]#struct#

Type representing the support of virtio-SCSI.
If it supported we use virtio driver for SCSI guest device.

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`enabled`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Enable Virtio SCSI support.

|===

[id="types/virtual_numa_node"]
=== VirtualNumaNode [small]#struct#

Represents the virtual NUMA node.

An example XML representation:

[source,xml]

<vm_numa_node href="/ovirt-engine/api/vms/123/numanodes/456" id="456"> <cpu> <cores> <core> <index>0</index> </core> </cores> </cpu> <index>0</index> <memory>1024</memory> <numa_node_pins> <numa_node_pin> <index>0</index> </numa_node_pin> </numa_node_pins> <vm href="/ovirt-engine/api/vms/123" id="123" /> </vm_numa_node>

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`comment`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Free text containing comments about this object.

|`cpu`
|<<types/cpu,Cpu>>
|

|`description`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable description in plain text.

|`id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A unique identifier.

|`index`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|

|`memory`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|Memory of the NUMA node in MB.

|`name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable name in plain text.

|`node_distance`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`numa_node_pins`
|<<types/numa_node_pin,NumaNodePin[]>>
|

|===

.Links summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`host`
|<<types/host,Host>>
|

|`statistics`
|<<types/statistic,Statistic[]>>
|Each host NUMA node resource exposes a statistics sub-collection for host NUMA node specific statistics.

|`vm`
|<<types/vm,Vm>>
|

|===

[id="types/virtual_numa_node/links/statistics"]
==== statistics

Each host NUMA node resource exposes a statistics sub-collection for host NUMA node specific statistics.

An example of an XML representation:

[source,xml]

<statistics> <statistic href="/ovirt-engine/api/hosts/123/numanodes/456/statistics/789" id="789"> <name>memory.total</name> <description>Total memory</description> <kind>gauge</kind> <type>integer</type> <unit>bytes</unit> <values> <value> <datum>25165824000</datum> </value> </values> <host_numa_node href="/ovirt-engine/api/hosts/123/numanodes/456" id="456" /> </statistic> …​ </statistics>

NOTE: This statistics sub-collection is read-only.

The following list shows the statistic types for a host NUMA node:

|===
|Name |Description

|`memory.total`
|Total memory in bytes on the NUMA node.

|`memory.used`
|Memory in bytes used on the NUMA node.

|`memory.free`
|Memory in bytes free on the NUMA node.

|`cpu.current.user`
|Percentage of CPU usage for user slice.

|`cpu.current.system`
|Percentage of CPU usage for system.

|`cpu.current.idle`
|Percentage of idle CPU usage.
|===

[id="types/vlan"]

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`id`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|Virtual LAN ID.

|===

[id="types/vm"]
=== Vm [small]#struct#

Represents a virtual machine.

.Attributes summary
[cols="20,20,60"]
|===
|Name |Type |Summary

|`bios`
|<<types/bios,Bios>>
|Reference to virtual machine's BIOS configuration.

|`comment`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Free text containing comments about this object.

|`console`
|<<types/console,Console>>
|Console configured for this virtual machine.

|`cpu`
|<<types/cpu,Cpu>>
|The configuration of the virtual machine CPU.

|`cpu_shares`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|

|`creation_time`
|<<types/date,Date>>
|The virtual machine creation date.

|`custom_compatibility_version`
|<<types/version,Version>>
|Virtual machine custom compatibility version.

|`custom_cpu_model`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`custom_emulated_machine`
|<<types/string,String>>
|

|`custom_properties`
|<<types/custom_property,CustomProperty[]>>
|Properties sent to VDSM to configure various hooks.

|`delete_protected`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|If `true`, the virtual machine cannot be deleted.

|`description`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable description in plain text.

|`display`
|<<types/display,Display>>
|The virtual machine display configuration.

|`domain`
|<<types/domain,Domain>>
|Domain configured for this virtual machine.

|`fqdn`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Fully qualified domain name of the virtual machine.

|`guest_operating_system`
|<<types/guest_operating_system,GuestOperatingSystem>>
|What operating system is installed on the virtual machine.

|`guest_time_zone`
|<<types/time_zone,TimeZone>>
|What time zone is used by the virtual machine (as returned by guest agent).

|`has_illegal_images`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Indicates whether the virtual machine has snapshots with disks in `ILLEGAL` state.

|`high_availability`
|<<types/high_availability,HighAvailability>>
|The virtual machine high availability configuration.

|`id`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A unique identifier.

|`initialization`
|<<types/initialization,Initialization>>
|Reference to the virtual machine's initialization configuration.

|`io`
|<<types/io,Io>>
|For performance tuning of IO threading.

|`large_icon`
|<<types/icon,Icon>>
|Virtual machine's large icon.

|`lease`
|<<types/storage_domain_lease,StorageDomainLease>>
|Reference to the storage domain this virtual machine/template lease reside on.

|`memory`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|The virtual machine's memory, in bytes.

|`memory_policy`
|<<types/memory_policy,MemoryPolicy>>
|Reference to virtual machine's memory management configuration.

|`migration`
|<<types/migration_options,MigrationOptions>>
|Reference to configuration of migration of running virtual machine to another host.

|`migration_downtime`
|<<types/integer,Integer>>
|Maximum time the virtual machine can be non responsive during its live migration to another host in ms.

|`multi_queues_enabled`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|If `true`, each virtual interface will get the optimal number of queues, depending on the available virtual Cpus.

|`name`
|<<types/string,String>>
|A human-readable name in plain text.

|`next_run_configuration_exists`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|Virtual machine configuration has been changed and requires restart of the virtual machine.

|`numa_tune_mode`
|<<types/numa_tune_mode,NumaTuneMode>>
|How the NUMA topology is applied.

|`origin`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The origin of this virtual machine.

|`os`
|<<types/operating_system,OperatingSystem>>
|Operating system type installed on the virtual machine.

|`payloads`
|<<types/payload,Payload[]>>
|Optional payloads of the virtual machine, used for ISOs to configure it.

|`placement_policy`
|<<types/vm_placement_policy,VmPlacementPolicy>>
|The configuration of the virtual machine's placement policy.

|`rng_device`
|<<types/rng_device,RngDevice>>
|Random Number Generator device configuration for this virtual machine.

|`run_once`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|If `true`, the virtual machine has been started using the _run once_ command, meaning
it's configuration might differ from the stored one for the purpose of this single run.

|`serial_number`
|<<types/serial_number,SerialNumber>>
|Virtual machine's serial number in a cluster.

|`small_icon`
|<<types/icon,Icon>>
|Virtual machine's small icon.

|`soundcard_enabled`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|If `true`, the sound card is added to the virtual machine.

|`sso`
|<<types/sso,Sso>>
|Reference to the Single Sign On configuration this virtual machine is configured for.

|`start_paused`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|If `true`, the virtual machine will be initially in 'paused' state after start.

|`start_time`
|<<types/date,Date>>
|The date in which the virtual machine was started.

|`stateless`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|If `true`, the virtual machine is stateless - it's state (disks) are rolled-back after shutdown.

|`status`
|<<types/vm_status,VmStatus>>
|The current status of the virtual machine.

|`status_detail`
|<<types/string,String>>
|Human readable detail of current status.

|`stop_reason`
|<<types/string,String>>
|The reason the virtual machine was stopped.

|`stop_time`
|<<types/date,Date>>
|The date in which the virtual machine was stopped.

|`storage_error_resume_behaviour`
|<<types/vm_storage_error_resume_behaviour,VmStorageErrorResumeBehaviour>>
|Determines how the virtual machine will be resumed after storage error.

|`time_zone`
|<<types/time_zone,TimeZone>>
|The virtual machine's time zone set by oVirt.

|`tunnel_migration`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|If `true`, the network data transfer will be encrypted during virtual machine live migration.

|`type`
|<<types/vm_type,VmType>>
|Determines whether the virtual machine is optimized for desktop or server.

|`usb`
|<<types/usb,Usb>>
|Configuration of USB devices for this virtual machine (count, type).

|`use_latest_template_version`
|<<types/boolean,Boolean>>
|If `true`, the virtual machine is reconfigured to the latest version of it's template when it is started.

|`virtio_scsi`
|<<types/virtio_scsi,VirtioScsi>>
|Reference to VirtIO SCSI configuration.

|===

[id="types/vm/attributes/cpu"]
==== cpu

The configuration of the virtual machine CPU.

The socket configuration can be updated without rebooting the virtual machine. The cores and the threads require
a reboot.

For example, to change the number of sockets to 4 immediately, and the number of cores and threads to 2 after
reboot, send the following request:

[source]

PUT /ovirt-engine/api/vms/123

With a request body:

[source,xml]

<vm> <cpu> <topology> <sockets>4</sockets> <cores>2</cores> <threads>2</threads> </topology> </cpu> </vm>

[id="types/vm/attributes/custom_compatibility_version"]
==== custom_compatibility_version

Virtual machine custom compatibility version.

Enables a virtual machine to be customized to its own compatibility version.  If
`custom_compatibility_version` is set, it overrides the cluster's compatibility version
for this particular virtual machine.

The compatibility version of a virtual machine is limited by the data center the virtual
machine resides in, and is checked against capabilities of the host the virtual machine is
planned to run on.

[id="types/vm/attributes/high_availability"]
==== high_availability

The virtual machine high availability configuration.
If set, the virtual machine will be automatically restarted when it unexpectedly goes down.

[id="types/vm/attributes/initialization"]
==== initialization

Reference to the virtual machine's initialization configuration.

NOTE: Since {product-name} 4.1.8 this property can be cleared by sending an empty tag.

For example, to clear the `initialization` attribute send a request like this:

[source]

PUT /ovirt-engine/api/vms/123

With a request body like this:

[source,xml]

<vm> <initialization/> </vm>

The response to such a request, and requests with the header `All-Content: true` will still contain this attribute.

[id="types/vm/attributes/large_icon"]
==== large_icon

Virtual machine's large icon. Either set by user or refers to image set according to operating system.

[id="types/vm/attributes/lease"]
==== lease

Reference to the storage domain this virtual machine/template lease reside on.

A virtual machine running with a lease requires checking while running that the lease is not taken by another
host, preventing another instance of this virtual machine from running on another host.
This provides protection against split-brain in highly available virtual machines.
A template can also have a storage domain defined for a lease in order to have the virtual machines created
from this template to be preconfigured with this storage domain as the location of the leases.

[id="types/vm/attributes/memory"]
==== memory

The virtual machine's memory, in bytes.

For example, to update a virtual machine to contain 1 Gibibyte (GiB) of memory, send the following request:

[source]

PUT /ovirt-engine/api/vms/123

With the following request body:

[source,xml]

<vm> <memory>1073741824</memory> </vm>

Memory hot plug is supported from {product-name} 3.6 onwards. You can use the example above to increase
memory while the virtual machine is in state <<types/vm_status/values/up, up>>. The size increment must be
dividable by the value of the `HotPlugMemoryBlockSizeMb` configuration value (256 MiB by default). If the memory
size increment is not dividable by this value, the memory size change is only stored to next run configuration.
Each successful memory hot plug operation creates one or two new memory devices.

Memory hot unplug is supported since {product-name} 4.2 onwards. Memory hot unplug can only be performed
when the virtual machine is in state <<types/vm_status/values/up, up>>. Only previously hot plugged memory
devices can be removed by the hot unplug operation. The requested memory decrement is rounded down to match sizes
of a combination of previously hot plugged memory devices. The requested memory value is stored to next run
configuration without rounding.

NOTE: Memory in the example is converted to bytes using the following formula: +
1 GiB = 2^30^ bytes = 1073741824 bytes.

NOTE: {engine-name} internally rounds values down to whole MiBs (1MiB = 2^20^ bytes)

[id="types/vm/attributes/migration_downtime"]
==== migration_downtime

Maximum time the virtual machine can be non responsive during its live migration to another host in ms.
